results.Policy Text: GSA Public Buildings Service PBS Procurement Instructional Bulletin 23-01 PUBLIC BUILDINGS SERVICE REGIONAL COMMISSIONERS ACQUISITION DIRECTORS TRACY MARCINOWSKI ASSISTANT COMMISSIONER OFFICE OF ACQUISITION MANAGEMENT (PQ) Mandatory Use of the Professional Acquisition Training Highway (PATH) Tool Date: MEMORANDUM FOR: FROM: SUBJECT: 1. Purpose The purpose of this Procurement Instructional Bulletin (PIB) is to outline the guidelines for implementation and use of the Professional Acquisition Training Highway (PATH) tool. 2. Background The Skill Enhancement & Employee Development (SEED) program was created to provide the 1102 contract specialist community with a solid foundation, minimize acquisition skill gaps, and increase the overall knowledge and skills of the acquisition workforce. As part of SEED, the PATH tool was developed to give those in the 1102 acquisition community with little to no contracting knowledge a tool to learn and test their knowledge using scenario based exercises. The tool consists of various exercises categorized into the following modules: Pre-Award, Award, Post-Award, and Other. 3. Effective Date This PIB is effective on the date signed. The exercises that make up the training tool will be updated, as needed, to address any regulatory changes or Office of Acquisition Management (OAM) policy guidance 1800 F Street, NW Washington, DC 20405-0002 www.gsa.gov DocuSign Envelope ID: 3DF787F3-F9CB-4240-B6F6-E46C4D13456610/28/2022 revisions. 4. Cancellation Date This PIB will remain in effect until canceled. 5. Affected or Canceled Policies None. 6. Applicability This PIB applies to all Public Buildings Service (PBS) 1102s, including interns hired under the PBS Acquisition Intern Program. Use of the PATH tool is mandatory for new employees at the GS-09 level and below who are hired on or after the effective date of this tool. The tool is optional for those employees above the GS-09 level. 7. Exceptions The requirements of this PIB will not be applicable to employees who are participating under the Emerging Leaders Program (ELP), until they are converted to the 1102 series. 8. Instructions and Procedures Exercises & Answer Keys The exercises are broken into four modules: Pre-award, Award, Post-Award, and Other. There are two documents for each topic: the exercise and answer key. Links to all of the documents can be found on Attachment 1 - PATH Tool Table of Contents. Users should complete the exercises in chronological order. Some exercises have a service and construction type scenario. In those cases, users can elect to complete one or both exercises. The users will access the exercise, read the scenario, if one is included, and use the policy and guidance references to answer the questions. Only the regional supervisors will have access to the answer key documents. Upon completion of each exercise, users must work with their supervisor, or designee, to review their responses and compare them to the answer key. This will help ensure that users understand the general concepts of the exercise topic. 2 DocuSign Envelope ID: 3DF787F3-F9CB-4240-B6F6-E46C4D134566 New employees will be expected to complete the entire tool within 18 months of their start date. At a minimum, the first module (Pre-Award) is to be completed within the first year. FAI CSOD & CLPs Upon completion of all exercises in a module, users are to ensure that their completion is indicated in FAI Cornerstone OnDemand (CSOD). To do this, supervisors are to complete the survey form linked as Attachment 2 - PATH Tool Supervisor Confirmation of Completion. Upon receipt, OAM will update FAI CSOD. This must be done for completion of each module. OAM will use this information to track completion of the tool. This process will also assist to provide continuous learning points (CLPs) to users who are eligible to receive them. 9. Point of Contact Any questions regarding the content of this PIB may be directed to Gabriela Sanchez, Procurement Analyst, Office of Acquisition Management, by email at gabriela.sanchez@gsa.gov. 10. Attachments Attachment 1 - PATH Tool Exercises via the Table of Contents Attachment 2 - PATH Tool Supervisor Confirmation of Completion 3 DocuSign Envelope ID: 3DF787F3-F9CB-4240-B6F6-E46C4D134566
results.EO_Text: Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 71 / Tuesday, April 15, 2025 / Presidential Documents 15629 Presidential Documents Executive Order 14267 of April 9, 2025 Reducing Anti-Competitive Regulatory Barriers By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, it is hereby ordered: Section 1. Purpose. Federal regulations should not predetermine economic winners and losers. Yet some regulations operate to exclude new market entrants. Regulations that reduce competition, entrepreneurship, and innova- tion as well as the benefits they create for American consumers should be eliminated. This order commences the process for eliminating anti-com- petitive regulations to revitalize the American economy. Sec. 2. Definitions. (a)  Agency  has the meaning given to it in section 3502 of title 44, United States Code, except that it does not include the Executive Office of the President or any components thereof. (b)  Agency head  means the highest-ranking official of an agency, such as the Secretary, Administrator, Chairman, or Director, unless otherwise specified in this order. Sec. 3. Rescinding Anti-Competitive Regulations. (a) Agency heads shall, in consultation with the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission (Chair- man) and the Attorney General, complete a review of all regulations subject to their rulemaking authority and identify those that: (i) create, or facilitate the creation of, de facto or de jure monopolies; (ii) create unnecessary barriers to entry for new market participants; (iii) limit competition between competing entities or have the effect of limiting competition between competing entities; (iv) create or facilitate licensure or accreditation requirements that unduly limit competition; (v) unnecessarily burden the agency s procurement processes, thereby lim- iting companies  ability to compete for procurements; or (vi) otherwise impose anti-competitive restraints or distortions on the oper- ation of the free market. (b) Within 70 days of the date of this order, agency heads shall each provide to the Chairman and the Attorney General a list of regulations identified by the categories specified in subsection (a) of this section. Agency heads shall also include a recommendation as to whether each of the listed regulations warrants rescission or modification in light of its anti-competitive effects. For recommended modifications, agency heads shall briefly specify what modification is appropriate. For regulations that are anti-competitive by design, agency heads shall provide a justification for their anti-competitive effects if the agency head is not proposing rescission or modification. (c) In conducting the review required by subsection (a) of this section, agency heads shall prioritize review of those rules that satisfy the definition of  significant regulatory action  in Executive Order 12866 of September 30, 1993 (Regulatory Planning and Review), as amended. (d) Within 10 days of the date of this order, the Chairman shall issue a request for information (RFI) that seeks public input on the identification of regulations that fall within the categories specified in subsection (a) of this section, as well as comments explaining the proposed classifications. The request shall remain open for 40 days. Upon the close of the RFI VerDate Sep<11>2014 16:28 Apr 14, 2025 Jkt 265001 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 4790 Sfmt 4790 E:\FR\FM\15APE4.SGM 15APE4 4 C O D Z E R P _ R F h t i w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o r e t t o l 15630 Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 71 / Tuesday, April 15, 2025 / Presidential Documents period, the Chairman shall convey any relevant responses to the agency with rulemaking authority over the identified regulation. (e) Within 90 days of receipt of the agency lists specified in subsection (b) of this section, the Chairman, in consultation with the Attorney General, the Assistant to the President for Economic Policy, and the relevant agency heads, shall provide to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB Director) a consolidated list of regulations that warrant rescission or modification in light of their anti-competitive effects, along with rec- ommended modifications. The Chairman may include on the consolidated list regulations not originally included on an agency list if such regulations fall within at least one of the categories outlined in subsections (a)(i)  (vi) of this section. (f) Upon receipt of the consolidated list described in subsection (e) of this section, the OMB Director, through the Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, shall consult with the Chairman, the Attorney General, the Assistant to the President for Economic Policy, and the relevant agency heads to decide whether to incorporate the proposed rescissions or modifications into the Unified Regulatory Agenda developed pursuant to Executive Order 14219 of February 19, 2025 (Ensuring Lawful Governance and Implementing the President s  Department of Government Efficiency  Deregulatory Initiative). Sec. 4. General Provisions. (a) Nothing in this order shall be construed to impair or otherwise affect: (i) the authority granted by law to an executive department or agency, or the head thereof; or (ii) the functions of the Director of the Office of Management and Budget relating to budgetary, administrative, or legislative proposals. (b) This order shall be implemented consistent with applicable law and subject to the availability of appropriations. (c) This order is not intended to, and does not, create any right or benefit, substantive or procedural, enforceable at law or in equity by any party against the United States, its departments, agencies, or entities, its officers, employees, or agents, or any other person. 4 C O D Z E R P _ R F h t i w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o r e t t o l THE WHITE HOUSE, April 9, 2025. results.Summary:
Policy Analysis Summary

1. Policy Summary (GSA Public Buildings Service PBS Procurement Instructional Bulletin 23-01):
The policy outlines the mandatory use of the Professional Acquisition Training Highway (PATH) tool for Public Buildings Service (PBS) contract specialists. Specifically, it requires:
- Mandatory training for new employees at GS-09 level and below
- Completion of training modules within 18 months of start date
- Tracking of completion through FAI Cornerstone OnDemand (CSOD)
- Focus on skill enhancement for the 1102 contract specialist community

2. Executive Order Summary:
The executive order aims to reduce anti-competitive regulatory barriers by:
- Requiring agencies to review and identify regulations that:
  a) Create monopolies
  b) Create barriers to market entry
  c) Limit competition
  d) Impose unnecessary regulatory constraints
- Mandating a comprehensive review of existing regulations
- Seeking public input on potentially anti-competitive regulations

3. Applicability Analysis:
After careful review, this specific policy does NOT appear to be directly impacted by the executive order for the following reasons:
- The PATH tool is an internal training mechanism
- It does not create market barriers or limit competition
- The policy is focused on employee skill development
- The training program does not regulate market access or business operations

4. Recommended Next Steps:
While immediate action is not required, GSA should:
- Retain the current policy as is
- During the next policy review, document how the PATH tool supports, rather than limits, competitive acquisition practices
- Be prepared to provide documentation if requested during the executive order's regulatory review process
- Ensure transparency in the training program's objectives and implementation

Caveat: This analysis is based on the available documents and represents a preliminary assessment. Formal legal review is recommended for definitive guidance.

Would you like me to elaborate on any part of this analysis?
results.updated_summary: The PBS Procurement Training Policy is an internal employee development tool that does not impose external market restrictions, regulatory barriers, or competitive limitations, thus falling outside the executive order's primary scope of reducing anti-competitive regulatory constraints.
results.phase1_response:
As a policy analyst for the General Services Administration (GSA), I have reviewed the provided documents to determine if Procurement Instructional Bulletin (PIB) 23-01 is affected by Executive Order 14267.

Here is a summary of my findings:

### 1. Summary of the Policy Text (GSA PIB 23-01)
The policy, GSA Public Buildings Service (PBS) Procurement Instructional Bulletin 23-01, establishes the mandatory use of the Professional Acquisition Training Highway (PATH) tool for certain employees. The PATH tool is an internal training program designed to build foundational knowledge for new contract specialists (1102 series) at the GS-09 level and below. It provides scenario-based exercises across Pre-Award, Award, and Post-Award procurement phases. The policy outlines the procedures for completing the training, supervisor involvement in reviewing answers, and the process for tracking completion to award Continuous Learning Points (CLPs). This is an internal workforce development and training policy.

### 2. Summary of the Executive Order Text (EO 14267)
Executive Order 14267, "Reducing Anti-Competitive Regulatory Barriers," directs federal agencies to review their regulations and identify any that create unnecessary barriers to economic competition. The stated purpose is to eliminate regulations that hinder new market entrants, limit competition, or otherwise distort the free market. The order specifically instructs agency heads to identify rules that, among other things, create monopolies, establish unnecessary barriers to entry for companies, or "unnecessarily burden the agency's procurement processes, thereby limiting companies' ability to compete for procurements."

### 3. Detailed Explanation of Applicability
This Executive Order **does not apply** to GSA PIB 23-01. The core distinction lies in the nature and scope of the two documents.

*   **Target of the Executive Order:** The EO is focused on external-facing **regulations** that impact the public and private sectors, specifically those that govern market dynamics and competition. Its aim is to identify and remove rules that negatively affect companies, entrepreneurs, and the economy. Section 3(a)(v) targets rules that burden the procurement process for outside companies seeking to do business with the government.
*   **Nature of the Policy Document:** The PIB is an **internal policy bulletin**, not an external regulation. Its purpose is to manage the professional development and training of GSA's own employees. It dictates how GSA trains its acquisition workforce; it does not impose any requirements, burdens, or conditions on external entities (e.g., contractors, vendors, or potential bidders).

While the PIB relates to the acquisition workforce, it does not "unnecessarily burden the agency's procurement processes" in the manner contemplated by the Executive Order. In fact, the policy's goal is to improve the skills of the acquisition workforce, which should lead to a more efficient, knowledgeable, and consistently run procurement process. A well-trained workforce is less likely to create undue burdens on industry. The PATH tool is an internal training mechanism, not a barrier to market entry or a limitation on corporate competition for government contracts.

Therefore, the PIB falls outside the scope of the regulatory review mandated by EO 14267.

### 4. Next Steps to Achieve Compliance
Because the policy is not affected by the Executive Order, no direct action is required for PIB 23-01.

*   No modification or rescission of PIB 23-01 is necessary as a result of EO 14267.
*   This policy bulletin does not need to be included in the list of regulations that GSA provides to the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission and the Attorney General under Section 3(b) of the EO.
*   GSA should proceed with the agency-wide review of its external-facing regulations as mandated by the Executive Order, focusing on rules that directly impact market competition and procurement access for outside companies.

***

**Final Determination: [Not Affected]**
results.phase2_justification:
1.  **The specific domain/subject area of the policy:** The policy, GSA Public Buildings Service (PBS) Procurement Instructional Bulletin 23-01, is an internal administrative directive focused on workforce development and training. Its specific purpose is to mandate the use of the "Professional Acquisition Training Highway (PATH)" tool for new acquisition employees (1102 contract specialists) at the GS-09 level and below. This policy governs the internal procedures for training government personnel to enhance their procurement skills.

2.  **The specific domain/subject area of the executive order:** Executive Order 14267, "Reducing Anti-Competitive Regulatory Barriers," is an economic and regulatory policy directive. Its goal is to identify and eliminate federal regulations that negatively impact free-market competition. It targets rules that create monopolies, erect barriers to market entry for new companies, and hinder the ability of businesses to compete for government contracts.

3.  **Detailed analysis of whether there is direct or indirect impact:** There is no direct or indirect impact of EO 14267 on PIB 23-01. The policy and the executive order operate in entirely separate spheres. The policy is inward-facing, governing the training and development of federal employees. The EO is outward-facing, concerned with the effect of federal regulations on the external marketplace and private sector entities. The training requirements outlined in the PIB do not create any burdens, barriers, or rules that private companies must follow to compete for government procurements.

4.  **Key language or provisions that support your determination:**
    *   **Policy (PIB 23-01):** The key language focuses entirely on internal personnel management: "The purpose of this Procurement Instructional Bulletin (PIB) is to outline the guidelines for implementation and use of the Professional Acquisition Training Highway (PATH) tool." and "This PIB applies to all Public Buildings Service (PBS) 1102s, including interns..." This confirms its scope is limited to GSA employees.
    *   **Executive Order (EO 14267):** The key provisions target regulations that "create unnecessary barriers to entry for new market participants," "limit competition between competing entities," or "unnecessarily burden the agency s procurement processes, thereby limiting companies’ ability to compete for procurements." The PIB does none of these things; it is a tool to improve the workforce, not a rule that constrains the market.

5.  **Any nuances or edge cases considered in your assessment:** One could argue that a better-trained acquisition workforce might lead to more efficient and competitive procurement processes, which is broadly aligned with the spirit of the EO. However, this is a beneficial, second-order outcome and not a direct regulatory impact. The EO is concerned with eliminating regulations that *create* anti-competitive barriers, not assessing internal training policies that may indirectly improve market efficiency. The PIB is an instructional bulletin for internal management, not a "regulation" in the sense targeted by the EO, which affects public and private entities. Therefore, the policy falls outside the scope of the EO's review mandate.

results.Policy Text: GENERAL SERVICES ADMINISTRATION Washington, DC 20405 GSA ORDER SUBJECT: Sustainability Performance 1. Purpose. PBS 1098.1 January 11, 2023 This Order directs and reiterates the Public Buildings Service s (PBS) continued commitment to sustainability performance across the owned and leased real property portfolio. The Order s overarching goals are to improve asset performance; reduce energy use, water use, waste generation, and greenhouse gas emissions; increase the number of all-electric buildings, net zero energy, and high performance sustainable Federal buildings; and achieve portfolio-wide net zero operational emissions by 2045. This Order supports proper focus, engagement, collaboration, planning, and accountability across PBS business lines and regions. 2. Background. GSA is a key leader in the Federal Government s real estate management and optimization efforts. PBS is charged with designing, constructing, operating, and maintaining a right-sized and sustainable Federal building portfolio that supports Federal operations now and for future generations. PBS expects to experience long- term increases in energy and water costs, and there are growing concerns about air quality, environmental stewardship, and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. PBS is taking action by deploying policies and programs to control operating costs, reduce environmental impacts, and improve overall building performance. Sustainability performance goals include but are not limited to:   Reduction of Greenhouse Gas Emissions;   Generation and Purchase of Carbon Pollution-Free Electricity;   Reduction of Energy and Water Usage, and Generation of Solid Waste;   Enhanced Indoor Environmental Quality;   Reduction of Operating Costs; 1 DocuSign Envelope ID: EB036CCD-245A-4ADA-A165-0DD7427071E2 PBS 1098.1   Development and Utilization of Specifications for Sustainable Materials and Products;   Locating, Designing, and Reinvesting into Federal Facilities to Promote Sustainable and Equitable Development;   Promoting Environmental Justice in Neighboring Communities;   Designing, Constructing, and Operating Sustainable and Resilient Buildings; and   Incorporating Regenerative Systems. The continued transformation of the PBS portfolio to meet new post-pandemic future of work customer requirements will help advance flexible and innovative solutions to meet the evolving workplace needs of diverse customer agencies. Further transitioning to a high performance sustainable Federal portfolio will help PBS cost-effectively maintain and improve its workplace solutions for the long-term benefit of both tenants and American taxpayers. 3. Scope and Applicability. This Order applies to all PBS business lines, programs, and initiatives that involve acquisition, planning, design, construction, operation, maintenance, lease, renovation, and disposal of Federally-owned facilities. Nothing in this Order changes the applicability and policy of when and how the GSA Facilities Standards for the Public Buildings Service applies to projects. 4. Policy. This Order formalizes core business practices, roles, and guidelines for PBS to achieve its sustainability performance goals. All PBS business lines must ensure appropriate policies, procedures, and measures are in place to provide for the continued use, appropriate care, and enhanced sustainability of Federally-owned buildings and leased space. Each PBS business line and region will update or expand its policies, guidance, and business practices as necessary to implement this Order. This Order supports existing PBS, GSA, and Federal mandates or policies including but not limited to:   PBS Strategic Plan 2022-26;   GSA Facilities Standards for the Public Buildings Service (P100);   GSA Sustainability Plan 2022;   GSA Agency Performance Plan;   GSA Strategic Plan 2022-26;   White House Council on Environmental Quality (CEQ), Guiding Principles for Sustainable Federal Buildings (Guiding Principles);   CEQ, Federal Building Performance Standard; DocuSign Envelope ID: EB036CCD-245A-4ADA-A165-0DD7427071E2 PBS 1098.1   48 C.F.R. Part 23, Environment, Energy and Water Efficiency, Renewable Energy Technologies, Occupational Safety, and Drug-Free Workplace;   10 C.F.R. Part 436, Federal Energy Management and Planning Programs;   40 U.S.C.   524, Duties of Executive Agencies;   41 C.F.R. Part 102-83, Location of Space;   42 U.S.C.   8262k, Government Contract Incentives;   42 U.S.C.   8254, Establishment of use of life cycle cost methods and procedures;   Federal Urban Land-Use Act, 40 U.S.C.   531 et seq.;   National Historic Preservation Act of 1966, as amended;   National Environmental Policy Act of 1969;   Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976;   National Energy Conservation Policy Act, as amended;   Public Buildings Cooperative Use Act of 1976, as amended;   Energy Policy Act of 2005;   Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007;   Energy Act of 2020;     Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act; and Inflation Reduction Act of 2022. a. Governance and Engagement. PBS business lines and regional leaders shall participate in, engage with, and support PBS sustainability governance bodies. Regional Commissioners (or their proxies) shall chair, re-establish, and support Regional Sustainability Councils (RSCs). New or existing cross functional teams should be established across business lines at the implementation, planning, and/or senior level as needed. Challenges should be raised to regional leadership and shared for visibility with the Regional Sustainability Council, the PBS National Sustainability Council (NSC), and, as appropriate, the PBS Sustainability Governance Board (SGB). b. Strategy. PBS business lines and regions will be held accountable for developing and complying with all current and forthcoming strategies, initiatives, actions, and measures to ensure goals of this Order are met. All business lines and divisions shall utilize sustainability status and building-level performance data for energy, water, waste, and GHG to set goals, milestones, and strategic plans. Performance data tools include but are not limited to: GHG Tracking Tools, National Computerized Maintenance Management System, Federal Real Property Profile, Smart Location Tool, and Energy Use and Analysis System. DocuSign Envelope ID: EB036CCD-245A-4ADA-A165-0DD7427071E2 PBS 1098.1 c. Sustainability Plans. PBS Regional Commissioners must establish a sustainability implementation plan (SIP) for their respective regions within 120 days of the date of this Order and update it annually thereafter. These regional SIPs will be reviewed by a subteam of the PBS NSC. Regional SIPs will be incorporated into the GSA Sustainability Strategic Plan and GSA Sustainability Report that will require concurrence by the PBS SGB. PBS Central Office will provide a regional SIP template. Plans must, at a minimum, cover roles and responsibilities, stakeholder engagement, and measures/metrics. GSA Sustainability Strategic Plan and Regional SIPs must make use of facility-level performance data for energy, water, and greenhouse gases. As the regional SIPs are developed and reviewed, best practices will be shared on the Climate & Sustainability Division s Insite page. Each region will provide quarterly quantitative and qualitative updates on progress toward its goals, including any challenges, to the NSC and, as appropriate, SGB. The PBS Climate and Sustainability Officer is responsible for coordinating these activities with the PBS Commissioner, Senior Leadership Team, SGB, NSC, Electric Vehicle PMO, and other business line staff as appropriate and communicating ongoing progress toward sustainability goals. d. Guidance. PBS Central Office business lines will provide guidance, as needed, and that should be reflected in the GSA Sustainability Strategic Plan and regional SIPs. All new and updated policy, guidance, and plans must be shared and reviewed by the PBS NSC and, if determined appropriate by the NSC chair, concurred on by the PBS SGB. e. Resourcing. PBS Central Office business lines and regions, in coordination with appropriate services and staff offices, shall focus on staffing and subject matter expert (SME) development, which could include, but is not limited to:   Developing and implementing staffing plans;   Hiring qualified new employees or contractors as needed;   Allowing additional location flexibility; DocuSign Envelope ID: EB036CCD-245A-4ADA-A165-0DD7427071E2 PBS 1098.1   Training existing employees to increase practical expertise and certifications (e.g., Certified Energy Manager, Measurement and Verification, and LEED Green Associate); and   Developing career ladders and succession plans. Energy management and sustainability focused requirements should, to the extent possible, be included in updated position descriptions for property, project, asset management and acquisition roles. All regions and business lines must enhance training and accountability. PBS Central Office business lines and regions should ensure that all programs and projects with potential to improve energy, water, materials, indoor environmental quality, resilience, or emissions performance are supported by appropriate subject matter expertise within and across business line functions. 5. Responsibilities. Responsibility for implementing this Order is shared broadly across and within each PBS business line and region. PBS Regional Commissioners and Assistant Commissioners shall instill a culture of ownership and accountability for the achievement of sustainable performance goals as outlined in this Order. Leadership shall cultivate and support expertise across business lines and roles at all levels to implement this Order. The scale and importance of this opportunity to create more efficient and effective Federal workspaces requires each PBS business line and region to understand, engage and support their employees, contractors, and customers in these efforts. a. Acquisition. The Acquisition business function is responsible for procurement of sustainable construction, operations, maintenance, and custodial services for PBS s buildings. As such, acquisition staff must ensure that vendors are adhering to contract requirements and that GSA stakeholders are actively working with vendors to ensure follow through on applicable sustainability guidance and reporting requirements. Acquisition business functions shall:   Encourage contracting officers to include and highlight requirements to use sustainable products, materials, and equipment, including energy- and water- consuming equipment, if life-cycle cost-effective, in new solicitations and resulting contract actions; DocuSign Envelope ID: EB036CCD-245A-4ADA-A165-0DD7427071E2 PBS 1098.1   Prioritize use of operations and maintenance vendors that have the capability to run buildings efficiently, to include energy management skill sets on staff;   Provide guidance on creating written acquisition plans that include robust sustainability sections covering, at a minimum, energy and water efficiency, waste, and GHG emission reduction;   Promote optimal use of performance contracting by improving Energy Savings Performance Contact (ESPC) and Utility Energy Service Contract (UESC) acquisition skills;   Educate contracting workforce on sustainable, low-carbon, and clean energy procurement;   Consider incorporating sustainable procurement goals into contracting staff performance plans; and   Train and maintain staff of dedicated sustainability SMEs to support acquisitions. b. Design and Construction. The Design and Construction business function is responsible for the design, renovation, and repair of PBS facilities. Office of Design and Construction shall coordinate across PBS to develop, revise, or socialize design and installation guides for:   Next generation cooling and heating technologies (to include Green Proving Ground (GPG) technologies and heat pump systems for space conditioning and water heating);   Renewable energy systems;   Grid-interactive efficient building technologies (to include energy storage and management systems);   Significant New Alternatives Policy refrigerant phaseout, pursuant to regulation and P100;   Passive energy strategies (to include air sealing, shading, energy recovery systems, and load management systems);   Regenerative or  living building  systems such as planted roofs, membrane bioreactors for water treatment, self-healing concrete, and carbon sequestration; and DocuSign Envelope ID: EB036CCD-245A-4ADA-A165-0DD7427071E2 PBS 1098.1   Site work at existing buildings that mitigates climate impacts from extreme heat, stormwater runoff, and similar conditions that impact offsite properties, particularly in communities with environmental justice concerns. The Design and Construction business function shall apply statutory, Executive Order, and P100 sustainability requirements, including but not limited to:   Design all new construction and modernizations to reduce fossil fuel-sourced energy by 80% for projects with concept design starts in or after FY2020; 90% for projects with concept designs in or after FY2025; and 100% for projects starting concept design in FY2030, as compared to a Commercial Buildings Energy Consumption Survey 2003 baseline, where life-cycle cost-effective;   For new construction and major modernization projects that finish concept design in FY2023 and later, comply with CEQ Federal Building Performance Standard and P100 electrification requirements;   Site new construction (in collaboration with Portfolio) and engage community stakeholders, including local officials, to advance environmental justice in compliance with 41 C.F.R. part 102-83, Location of Space, Guiding Principles for Sustainable Federal Buildings, and relevant Executive orders;   Use project-specific Community Engagement Plans to align project site and design strategies to support local planning, economic, sustainability, preservation, livability, and safety goals;   Starting with FY2023 design starts, target energy usage intensity 30% below ASHRAE 90.1-2019 for all new construction buildings (10 C.F.R. part 433);   Reduce the environmental impact of materials and products used in GSA projects such as concrete, asphalt, steel, and insulation, with a focus on  cradle to gate  embodied carbon GHG emissions associated with the materials  extraction and manufacture;   Reinvest sustainably in existing buildings (including prioritization of historic buildings accessible to public transportation and community infrastructure), where life-cycle cost-effective; and   For new construction and major modernization projects that finish concept design in FY2023 and later, perform whole-building life-cycle assessment to reduce total  cradle to grave  embodied carbon by 20%, compared to a modeled standard baseline building design. DocuSign Envelope ID: EB036CCD-245A-4ADA-A165-0DD7427071E2 PBS 1098.1 Design and Construction business functions must ensure that contract scopes include all applicable P100 sustainability requirements and that vendors adhere to these requirements. Where applicable to project scope, design and construction staff shall:   Use GSA s Energy Use Target Guidance and choose the most life-cycle cost- effective equipment;   Deliver net zero energy-ready new construction and major modernization projects;   Designate space on the site plan for photovoltaic panels sized to meet the building s energy demand to be added later;   Minimize the generation of municipal solid waste and non-hazardous construction and demolition waste, diverting at least 50% of both from landfills;   Engage performance contracting partners in Facilities Management to explore financing new (not previously-funded) scopes that improve efficiency or generate renewable power;   Deploy zero-emission energy technologies, such as all-electric heat pumps that consume zero fossil fuels during standard operations;   Reduce greenhouse gas emissions associated with the contractor operations (including at the job site) and embodied carbon associated with materials purchased by the contractor;   Ensure appropriate project teams have access to training on sustainable, low- carbon and clean energy procurement;   Consider incorporating sustainable design, construction, and procurement goals into project managers  and contracting officer s representatives  performance plans; and   Train personnel and maintain adequate levels of sustainability expertise to effectively support design and construction business functions, and achievement of the design and construction goals listed above. c. Facilities Management. The Facilities Management business function is responsible for the sustainable operations and maintenance of PBS facilities to maximize and support tenant agencies' ability to excel at their missions now and in the future. Facility DocuSign Envelope ID: EB036CCD-245A-4ADA-A165-0DD7427071E2 PBS 1098.1 management staff and supporting personnel must ensure that vendors are held accountable for compliance with current operations and maintenance, custodial, and lease contract requirements reflecting PBS s current sustainable performance standards, including but not limited to, the national Operations and Maintenance Contract Specification, National Custodial Specification, Green Lease Guidance, and P100. Contracting officer s representatives must fulfill their responsibilities by holding their vendors accountable to those requirements and maintaining access to the technical assistance resources required to achieve them. Facilities Management business functions shall:   Partner with other PBS business lines to achieve a net-zero emissions building portfolio by 2045;   Develop a carbon pollution-free electricity roadmap to procure 100% carbon pollution-free electricity on a net annual basis (and 50% 24/7 carbon pollution- free electricity) by 2030;   Develop staffing plans that support the development and training of all facility managers in the area of sustainable facilities management;   Develop and execute plans to maximize renewable energy generation;   Prepare buildings for grid-interactive capabilities;   Work with asset managers to develop building improvement plans that include:   Passive energy strategies that benefit energy reductions, tenant comfort, resiliency, electrification, and ability to achieve net zero site energy;   Documenting and reporting equipment deficiencies for inclusion in Five Year Plans; and   Developing a glide path to achieve a net zero emissions portfolio by 2045;   Follow P100 electrification requirements and pursue building electrification strategies, in accordance with the CEQ Federal Building Performance Standard;   Support all business functions in the use of performance contracting;   Support planning and installation of zero emission vehicle infrastructure;   Develop Annual Building-level Energy Plans to include:   Air sealing;   Energy and water conservation measures/savings projects;   Monthly progress reports (energy, water, refrigerants, and waste); and DocuSign Envelope ID: EB036CCD-245A-4ADA-A165-0DD7427071E2 PBS 1098.1   Utility bill monitoring and management;   Provide continuous feedback to design and construction staff on how to improve delivery of equipment and systems through the Operational Excellence program;   Provide training on sustainable facility operations and maintenance to all Facilities Management staff to include the Guiding Principles for Sustainable Federal Buildings criteria;   Ensure facility managers and lease asset managers continue to take required training per the Federal Buildings Personnel Training Act of 2010;   Consider incorporating sustainable operations goals into all Facilities Management performance plans;   Train and maintain staffing of dedicated sustainability SME support for Facilities Management business functions;   Monitor sustainability related compliance with contracts and leases through Management Analysis Review System and Procurement Management Reviews ; and   Identify Energy Conservation Measures (ECMs) that have not previously been funded and work to implement at least 50% of the life-cycle cost-effective ECMs using performance contracts. d. Leasing. The Leasing business function shall issue appropriate guidance in the form of new and revised leasing requirements to comply with current and future statutory, regulatory, and Executive Order mandates. The PBS Office of Leasing (OL) shall leverage the power of federal procurement to reduce carbon emissions and improve environmental sustainability in its leased space contracts. Leasing business functions shall:   Continue to identify critical sustainability requirements as mandatory provisions in GSA lease documents and track compliance through the annual green lease audit and program management reviews;   Include new lease contract requirements in all new, new-replacing, succeeding, and superseding lease solicitations issued after September 30, 2023 where the government will occupy at least 25,000 rentable square feet in a building and the DocuSign Envelope ID: EB036CCD-245A-4ADA-A165-0DD7427071E2 PBS 1098.1 Federal government leases at least 75 percent of the total building square footage. New mandated lease requirements include:   Tracking and reporting energy use, GHGs, water use, and waste generation; and   Ensuring compliance with sustainability reporting lease guidance and requirements;   Ensure new lease solicitations issued after September 30, 2030 that are greater than 25,000 rentable square feet and where the Federal government leases at least 75 percent of the total building square footage require that leased space be in net-zero emissions buildings, subject to market availability;   Provide training on sustainable leasing requirements to all leasing staff, including Lease Contracting Officers, Leasing Specialists, agencies delegated lease acquisition authority by GSA and National Broker partners;   Topics will include the Guiding Principles for Sustainable Federal Buildings; and   Train and maintain staffing of dedicated sustainability SME support for leasing business functions. e. Portfolio Management and Customer Engagement. Portfolio Management and Customer Engagement business functions shall be responsible for the development of asset business strategies and portfolio plans that target achieving a net-zero portfolio by 2045. Portfolio Management and Customer Engagement staff shall partner with customer agencies to garner support and cooperation in achieving sustainability goals. The GSA Sustainability Strategic Plan and regional SIPs will leverage facilities-level data, including energy and water intensity, Guiding Principles compliance, climate risk, and GHG emissions, as well as expertise of multiple business lines to inform portfolio strategies and decision- making related to acquisitions, investments, and divestments. Portfolio Management and Customer Engagement business functions shall:   Develop building-level reinvestment strategies and project budgets, incorporating input from sustainability SMEs, to meet the sustainability requirements of this Order in federal facilities that are considered long-term holds, taking into consideration various budget scenarios; DocuSign Envelope ID: EB036CCD-245A-4ADA-A165-0DD7427071E2 PBS 1098.1   Socialize asset-level strategies and holding periods across PBS business lines to ensure awareness across business functions;   Develop funding strategies to prepare for electrification of buildings and water heating, with a priority on assets that are considered long-term holds;   Prioritize implementation strategies by assets considered long-term holds and based on maximum lifetime GHG reduction per dollar invested across the PBS inventory;   Improve awareness and understanding of the importance of sustainability in planning by hosting Central Office training, tailored to the Portfolio Management and Customer Engagement communities, on sustainable building design, construction, and operations, including the CEQ Guiding Principles for Sustainable Federal Buildings;   Incorporate the best practices and principles from this training into asset business planning and customer engagement activities;   Engage Facilities Management to evaluate the use of performance contracting as a funding source to implement reinvestment strategies for long-term hold assets to improve efficiency and resilience of facilities, deploy clean technologies, and reduce GHGs from operations; and   Leverage staff expertise in sustainability across multiple business functions to support the development and execution of asset business strategies. Central Office Portfolio Management and Customer Engagement shall designate a sustainability subject matter expert to assist regional staff in integrating sustainability into planning. 6. Effective Date. This Order is effective immediately and will remain in effect until it is revised or canceled. 7. Signature. _____________________ Nina M. Albert Commissioner Public Buildings Service DocuSign Envelope ID: EB036CCD-245A-4ADA-A165-0DD7427071E2

results.EO_Text: Federal Register Vol. 90, No. 17 Tuesday, January 28, 2025 Title 3  The President Presidential Documents 8233 Proclamation 10885 of January 20, 2025 Flying the Flag of the United States at Full-Staff on Inau- guration Day By the President of the United States of America A Proclamation By the authority vested in me by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, and in honor of Inauguration Day and everything good and noble that it represents about our Nation, our people, and our form of Government, I hereby order that, on this and all future Inauguration Days, the flag of the United States shall be flown at full-staff. Accordingly, I hereby order that the flag of the United States shall be flown at full-staff at the White House and upon all public buildings and grounds, at all military posts and naval stations, and on all naval vessels of the Federal Government, in the District of Columbia and throughout the United States and its Territories and possessions, for the remainder of this day beginning immediately. I also direct that, for the same period of time, the flag shall be flown at full-staff at all United States embassies, legations, consular offices, and other facilities abroad, including all military facilities and naval vessels and stations. Upon the end of this Inauguration Day, I hereby order that the flag of the United States shall be returned to half-staff as directed by Proclamation 10876 of December 29, 2024 (Announcing the Death of James Earl Carter, Jr.), in recognition of the memory of our former President, until the period of 30 days from the day of his death has concluded. - 0 D C O D S E R P h t i w D O R P 3 2 N R 0 2 1 K S D n o r e l l e h m u r d d VerDate Sep<11>2014 15:48 Jan 27, 2025 Jkt 265001 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 4705 Sfmt 4790 E:\FR\FM\28JAD0.SGM 28JAD0 8234 Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 17 / Tuesday, January 28, 2025 / Presidential Documents IN WITNESS WHEREOF, I have hereunto set my hand this twentieth day of January, in the year of our Lord two thousand twenty-five, and of the Independence of the United States of America the two hundred and forty- ninth. results.Summary:
Here's a comprehensive policy analysis:

1. Policy Summary:
The GSA Public Buildings Service (PBS) Sustainability Performance Order (PBS 1098.1) provides comprehensive guidelines for achieving sustainability across federal real estate. Key goals include:
- Reducing energy, water, and waste usage
- Decreasing greenhouse gas emissions
- Achieving net zero operational emissions by 2045
- Improving building performance and environmental stewardship

2. Executive Order Summary:
The executive order is a Presidential Proclamation regarding flag protocols on Inauguration Day, specifically mandating full-staff flag display on Inauguration Day and returning to half-staff afterward in remembrance of a former president.

3. Applicability Analysis:
The executive order does NOT impact the PBS Sustainability Performance policy. The proclamation is solely about flag display protocols and does not:
- Modify sustainability regulations
- Change environmental performance standards
- Alter GSA's sustainability objectives
- Impact building management or emissions reduction goals

4. Compliance Next Steps:
No specific compliance actions are required, as the executive order is unrelated to the sustainability policy. The PBS Sustainability Performance Order remains fully in effect and should continue implementation as originally outlined.

Recommendation: Continue executing the sustainability policy according to its existing guidelines and timelines. No modifications are necessary based on this executive order.
results.updated_summary: The Executive Order is a narrowly scoped flag protocol proclamation that has no operational, regulatory, or strategic relationship to the PBS Sustainability Performance policy. There are no provisions that would require any modification to the existing sustainability guidelines.
results.phase1_response:
**MEMORANDUM FOR THE RECORD**

**FROM:** GSA Policy Analyst
**DATE:** October 26, 2023
**SUBJECT:** Analysis of the Impact of Proclamation 10885 on GSA Order PBS 1098.1 (Sustainability Performance)

This memorandum provides an analysis of whether Proclamation 10885 affects the implementation or substance of GSA Order PBS 1098.1.

### 1. Summary of Policy Text (GSA Order PBS 1098.1)
GSA Order PBS 1098.1, titled "Sustainability Performance," is a comprehensive internal directive for the Public Buildings Service (PBS). It outlines GSA's commitment to improving sustainability across its portfolio of owned and leased federal buildings. The policy's overarching goals are to reduce energy use, water consumption, waste, and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, with a target of achieving portfolio-wide net-zero operational emissions by 2045. The Order establishes specific responsibilities and actions for various PBS business lines, including Acquisition, Design and Construction, Facilities Management, Leasing, and Portfolio Management, to ensure these sustainability goals are integrated into all aspects of federal real estate management.

### 2. Summary of Executive Order Text (Proclamation 10885)
Proclamation 10885 is a presidential directive concerning the proper display of the flag of the United States on Inauguration Day, January 20, 2025. It orders that the flag be flown at full-staff on all public buildings, military installations, and U.S. facilities for the duration of that day. The proclamation was issued to honor Inauguration Day and temporarily supersedes a previous order that had directed flags to be flown at half-staff in memory of former President James Earl Carter, Jr. The order is specific, time-bound, and pertains exclusively to flag etiquette.

### 3. Detailed Explanation of Applicability
The executive order (Proclamation 10885) **does not apply to or affect** GSA Order PBS 1098.1.

The two documents govern entirely separate and non-overlapping domains.

*   **Subject Matter:** GSA Order PBS 1098.1 is a detailed, technical, and long-term policy focused on building performance, energy efficiency, sustainable procurement, and environmental stewardship. Its provisions relate to HVAC systems, building materials, energy contracts, and operational procedures. In contrast, Proclamation 10885 is a ceremonial directive concerning the symbolic display of the national flag.
*   **Scope of Directives:** The GSA Order directs internal business practices related to sustainability. The Proclamation directs a specific action (raising a flag) on a specific day.
*   **Lack of Conflict:** There is no conflict or interaction between the requirements of the two documents. Fulfilling the directive to fly the U.S. flag at full-staff has no bearing on the GSA's ability to reduce GHG emissions, procure carbon-free electricity, or implement sustainable design principles. Similarly, the sustainability policy does not contain any provisions related to flag display protocol.

While both documents apply to "public buildings," they address completely different aspects of those buildings' management and operation. One concerns the physical and environmental performance of the asset, while the other concerns a ceremonial protocol.

### 4. Next Steps to Achieve Compliance
As the executive order does not affect the policy, no actions are required to bring GSA Order PBS 1098.1 into compliance. PBS business lines should continue to focus on implementing the sustainability goals, plans, and responsibilities as outlined in GSA Order PBS 1098.1 without modification.

***

**Final Determination: Not Affected**
results.phase2_justification:
1.  **The specific domain/subject area of the policy**: The policy, GSA Order PBS 1098.1, "Sustainability Performance," establishes a comprehensive framework for the Public Buildings Service (PBS) to improve the environmental and sustainability performance of its real property portfolio. Its domain is squarely focused on technical and operational aspects of building management, including reducing energy and water consumption, lowering greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, achieving net-zero operational emissions, utilizing sustainable materials, and implementing sustainable design, construction, and leasing practices.

2.  **The specific domain/subject area of the executive order**: Presidential Proclamation 10885, "Flying the Flag of the United States at Full-Staff on Inauguration Day," has a very narrow and specific domain: ceremonial flag protocol. Its sole purpose is to mandate that the U.S. flag be flown at full-staff on all federal buildings and facilities on Inauguration Day.

3.  **Detailed analysis of whether there is direct or indirect impact**: There is no direct or indirect impact from Proclamation 10885 on GSA Order PBS 1098.1. The subject matters of the two documents are entirely unrelated.
    *   **No Direct Impact**: The proclamation does not alter, amend, supersede, or conflict with any of the goals, responsibilities, or procedures outlined in the sustainability policy. The requirements for building electrification, energy use intensity targets, sustainable procurement, or developing regional sustainability plans are completely unaffected by the protocol for displaying a flag.
    *   **No Indirect Impact**: The act of flying a flag at full-staff has no bearing on a building's energy consumption, water usage, waste generation, or GHG emissions. Compliance with the proclamation is a ceremonial, operational task that exists entirely separate from the long-term, strategic sustainability initiatives mandated by the GSA Order.

4.  **Key language or provisions that support your determination**:
    *   **Policy Text (PBS 1098.1)** focuses on terms such as "reduce energy use, water use, waste generation, and greenhouse gas emissions," "net zero operational emissions," "sustainable materials and products," "life-cycle cost-effective," and "building electrification strategies."
    *   **Order Text (Proclamation 10885)** focuses exclusively on the directive that "the flag of the United States shall be flown at full-staff... on this and all future Inauguration Days."
    The complete dissimilarity in the language and objectives of the two documents demonstrates their lack of relationship.

5.  **Any nuances or edge cases considered in your assessment**: While the GSA's Public Buildings Service is responsible for managing the "public buildings and grounds" upon which the flag must be flown, this responsibility is a routine operational duty. It does not intersect with the strategic planning, capital investment, procurement, and performance tracking required by the sustainability policy. Adherence to the flag proclamation is a distinct, parallel responsibility that does not influence the implementation or outcomes of GSA Order PBS 1098.1. Therefore, the policy is not affected.
