results.Policy Text: U.S. General Services Administration September 28, 2022 MEMORANDUM FOR: PBS REGIONAL COMMISSIONERS; REGIONAL DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION DIRECTORS; REGIONAL PORTFOLIO MANAGEMENT DIRECTORS; and ZONAL PBS FINANCIAL SERVICES DIRECTORS FROM: BRIAN BLOCK ACTING BUDGET DIRECTOR (BB) OFFICE OF BUDGET SUBJECT: Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act Financial Guidance This memorandum provides supplemental financial execution guidance regarding the $3,418,008,000 appropriated to the Federal Buildings Fund (FBF) by the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA), P.L. 117-58, 135 Stat. 429, 1382-1383. Throughout this memorandum, the IIJA will be referred to as the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law (BIL). Specifically, this memorandum establishes the following new tracking requirements in Section C:   Tracking of BIL program support costs using FBF Fund 192X:   Public Buildings Service (PBS) must use tracking code Y0000BIL in the accounting string for non-labor program requirements using 192X funding.   PBS shall begin timecarding administrative hours spent on BIL to HRLinks labor code Y0000BIL beginning 09/25/22 (pay period ending 10/8).   Does not apply to SES or Land Ports of Entry Program Management Office employees, or employees who can code time to an individual project or RWA. Future updates may be incorporated in subsequent memoranda should reporting requirements change or as other BIL execution requirements develop. If you have any questions regarding this guidance, please contact Nicole Diederich, Director OCFO, PBS Office of Budget unless otherwise noted. DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A Contents A. Overview B. New Accounting Codes 1. Fund 192J 2. Budget Activities 3. Function Codes and SOCs C. Tracking PBS Operating Expenses Related to BIL 1. Travel 2. Labor Coding/Timecarding 3. All Other D. Requesting BIL Funds 1. Allowance Process E. Pegasys 1. Pegasys Templates 2. Purchase Cards (non-travel) 3. Reports 4. G&A Allocation 5. Cost Transfers F. Property 1. Establishing 192J Funded Projects 2. Monitoring Capitalized Projects G. RWA Tracking H. PBS Systems I. FY 2022 and Beyond 2 3 4 4 4 5 6 6 6 6 6 7 8 8 8 8 9 9 10 10 11 12 13 14 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A A. Overview The President signed the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA), P.L. 117-58, 135 Stat. 429, on November 15, 2021 providing $3,418,008,000 to the U.S. General Services Administration for various work on border stations and land ports of entry. Throughout this document this act will be referred to as the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law (BIL). The relevant enacted language from the Act is as follows:  For an additional amount to be deposited in the  Federal Buildings Fund , $3,418,008,000, to remain available until expended, for construction and acquisition, and repairs and alterations of border stations and land ports of entry, of which no more than $250,000,000 shall be for Program Contingency and Operational Support for necessary expenses for projects funded under this heading, including, moving governmental agencies (including space alterations and adjustments, and telecommunications relocation expenses) in connection with the assignment, allocation and transfer of space, leasing of temporary space, and building operations, of which  (1) $2,527,808,000 shall be for projects on the U.S. Customs and Border Protection five-year plan; (2) $430,200,000 shall be for projects with completed U.S. Customs and Border Protection/General Services Administration feasibility studies as prioritized in the  American Jobs Plan Project List  submitted to the House and Senate Committees on Appropriations on May 28, 2021; and (3) $210,000,000 shall be for land ports of entry (LPOE) infrastructure paving; acquisition of leased LPOEs; and additional Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration requirements at the Southern Border: Provided, That the General Services Administration shall submit a plan, by project, regarding the use of funds made available to the Administrator under this heading in this Act to the Committees on Appropriations of the House of Representatives and the Senate within 90 days of enactment of this Act: Provided further, That the Administrator of General Services shall notify the Committees on Appropriations of the House of Representatives and the Senate quarterly on the obligations and expenditures of the funds provided under this heading in this Act by account of the Federal Buildings Fund: Provided further, That funds made available under this heading in this Act for Federal Buildings Fund activities may be transferred to, and merged with, other accounts within the Federal Buildings Fund only to the extent necessary to meet program requirements for such activities: Provided further, That the General Services Administration will provide notice in advance to the Committees on Appropriations of the House of Representatives and the Senate of any proposed transfers: Provided further, That funds made available to the Administrator under this heading in this Act shall not be subject to section 3307 of title 40, United States Code: Provided further, That amounts made available under this heading in this Act shall be in addition to any other amounts made available for such purposes, including for construction and acquisition or repairs and alterations: Provided further, That such amount is designated by the Congress as being 3 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A for an emergency requirement pursuant to section 4112(a) of H. Con. Res. 71 (115th Congress), the concurrent resolution on the budget for fiscal year 2018, and to section 251(b) of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985.  The Office of the Chief Financial Officer (OCFO) Office of Budget (BB), Financial Management (BG), and Office of PBS Financial Services (BR), together with the Public Buildings Service (PBS), drafted this guidance document for the management of the Federal Buildings Fund (FBF) BIL funds. B. New Accounting Codes 1. Fund 192J Fund 192J has been established in GSA s accounting system, Pegasys, for the use of PBS, and will be used specifically for the obligation of FBF funds appropriated by the BIL. The Treasury Account Symbol (TAS) for fund 192J is the same as the FBF; TAS 47X4542. Please note that the FBF, which is the traditional funding vehicle for PBS, is a no-year quasi-revolving fund and permits PBS to use new obligational authority until expended. As the enacted language states,  For an additional amount to be deposited in the  Federal Buildings Fund , $3,418,008,000, to remain available until expended .. , fund 192J will be structured as a no-year fund in Pegasys . BIL obligations and expenses must not be included in the regular FBF 192X account and reported as such, due to special reporting requirements stipulated for these funds under the Act and apportionment by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB). Therefore, for ease of reporting, the BIL funding must be tracked and managed separately, using a new fund (fund 192J). For financial reporting, all obligations and outlays will still be reported under the Federal Buildings Fund TAS 47X4542. 2. Budget Activities The BIL appropriated funds in five different spending categories. In order to track and manage each category within the spending plan and apportionment, five budget activities within 192J are created and listed below. These are established for use in fund 192J only, and cannot be used in fund 192X.   PG11 CBP LPOE Five Year Plan Projects: Land Ports of Entry (LPOE) projects on the U.S. Customs and Border Protection five-year plan.   PG12 AJP Priority LPOE Projects: projects with completed U.S. Customs and Border Protection/General Services Administration feasibility studies as prioritized in the  American Jobs Plan Project List  submitted to the House and Senate Committees on Appropriations on May 28, 2021. 4 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A   PG13 LPOE Paving, Acquisition of Leased LPOE, and FMCSA Projects: for LPOE infrastructure paving; acquisition of leased LPOEs; and additional Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) requirements at the Southern Border.   PG14 Program Contingency: This budget activity will be used for project contingency funds.   Per the public law:  no more than $250,000,000 shall be for Program Contingency and Operational Support for necessary expenses for projects funded under this heading, including, moving governmental agencies (including space alterations and adjustments, and telecommunications relocation expenses) in connection with the assignment allocation and transfer of space, leasing of temporary space, and building operations.    PG15 Operational Support: This budget activity will be used for operational support costs. This funding is capped at $250,000,000 along with the contingency.   Per the public law: no more than $250,000,000 shall be for Program Contingency and Operational Support for necessary expenses for projects funded under this heading, including, moving governmental agencies (including space alterations and adjustments, and telecommunications relocation expenses) in connection with the assignment allocation and transfer of space, leasing of temporary space, and building operations.   At this time, PBS does not plan to issue allowances for operational support from the BIL. Please see section C  Tracking PBS Operating Expenses Related to BIL . All current budget activities in fund 192X will continue to be used only for FBF activities as appropriated, and will not be available under fund 192J. Regular 192X and BIL 192J funding can be used in conjunction with each other on LPOE projects. These situations will be reviewed on a case-by-case basis in coordination with OCFO, PBS Portfolio, Office of the General Counsel, and the LPOE Program Management Office (PMO). The use of funds for PG11, PG12, PG13, PG14, and PG15 will be directly tied to the approved spending plan. The regions must adhere to the project list as provided in the spend plan. 3. Function Codes and SOCs The existing Function Codes and Sub-Object Classes (SOCs) for 192X will be used for fund 192J. Please apply accounting classification codes in accordance with normal coding guidelines depending on the purchase. Please refer to the PBS Standardized Coding website to find more information. 5 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A C. Tracking PBS Operating Expenses Related to BIL At this time, PBS does not plan to issue allowances for operational support from the BIL and all operating costs will be funded from regular FBF fund 192X. It is still necessary to track 192X costs related to executing the BIL projects. Tracking code Y0000BIL was set up in order to track BIL expenses paid for by regular 192X funding. 1. Travel At this time, all travel continues to be paid from 192X BA60. All travel in Concur for a BIL project need to cite the Y0000BIL tracking code. This code has been loaded in Concur for certain organization codes related to BIL. If the coding for your organization does not appear, please contact your Building Operations budget analyst. 2. Labor Coding/Timecarding Every PBS employee is to follow current business rules regarding timecarding their labor hours to function codes, buildings, projects, and reimbursable work authorizations (RWAs). Employees who work on BIL projects need to code their time to the specific projects as normal. Effective with the pay period beginning 9/25/22 (pay period ending 10/08), those who spend administrative time on BIL work need to code their time to Y0000BIL in HRLinks using the region s dummy building number. This does not apply to SES or PMO employees, or to PBS employees who can code time to individual projects or RWAs. Employees who work full time on BIL projects within the LPOE PMO do not need to timecard to the Y-code as their organization code is already delineated as full time BIL. Please see section E.4 for more information on General & Administrative (G&A) allocation. 3. All Other Management Support contract employees who are not working on a specific project must be coded to Sub Object Class H03 (Contract labor) with tracking code, Y0000BIL. The tracking code will enable GSA to separate out embedded contract employees from other types of contracts. The LPOE PMO must be notified of all new management support contracts supporting the BIL prior to award. All other costs not included in a project or in the BIL spend plan, but related to the BIL, such as training, will continue to use the Y0000BIL code for tracking in 192X. D. Requesting BIL Funds BIL funds will be managed by the PMO through internal tracking and spend planning. As regions prepare to make awards, regions should follow the standard allowance 6 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A request process, with BIL process clarifications below, to obtain the project funding in Pegasys. 1. Allowance Process For PG11-PG14, OCFO PBS Budget Division (BBP) will send instructions for regional project and budget teams to create line item project numbers in IRIS. The best practice is for regions to plan to request project allowances for each major project phase, including appropriate contingency, ensuring appropriate time before award, usually once contract awards are pending. The following procedural requirements for issuing allowances shall be followed:   All allowance request packets must be submitted to the allowance request mailbox (allowance.requests@gsa.gov).   The regional program office must coordinate with the zonal budget analyst to prepare the GSA form 3285 allowance request.   A completed GSA Form 3285 is required as an attachment to the allowance request email. The form must be filled out in its entirety to include all regional approving persons, the appropriation, and the amount that the region is requesting. Also, the description section must include which national spend plan the region is requesting funds from and the purpose for how the funds will be obligated. In addition to the GSA Form 3285, regions need to provide any applicable supporting documents to verify the actual award amount, such as, the contractor's proposal (i.e., Standard Form 1442), to support the allowance request.     Note: for all BIL studies (site acquisition, NEPA, pre-design) allowances, regions may provide the Independent Government Estimate as support.   The zonal budget office will then attach the GSA form 3285, supporting documents, spend plan and submit the funds request email to the Central Office allowance request mailbox (allowance.requests@gsa.gov).   Upon receiving the allowance request, BBP will review the allowance request and then forward the request for approval to the LPOE PMO and Office of Portfolio Management & Customer Engagement. Please allow a lead-time of approximately two days for the Central Office to review and concur.   After OCFO approvals have been obtained, BBP will complete the project allowance in Pegasys. After receiving notification that the allowance has been processed, the regional budget analyst must establish an operating plan (A5 level) in Pegasys.   The new PBS project management system, Kahua, will be automating the allowance creation and approval process. Once that feature is implemented, allowances will be created and routed in Kahua. 7 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A E. Pegasys 1. Pegasys Templates New Pegasys templates and budget activities have been added for fund 192J. Accounting templates for the below organization codes have been created for fund 192J. Templates for additional organization codes can be added as needed, please contact BBP with any questions or to request an organization code. Regional Org Codes available for 192J: An LPOE PMO has been established within Region 2. All PMO costs must be coded to organization code P02L0001. Pegasys accounting templates with the P02L0001 organization code have been created for 192X PG60, PG61 and 192J PG15. 2. Purchase Cards (non-travel) Purchase card users must log their BIL-related transactions into Pegasys using fund 192J, and must remember to perform a timely reconciliation. Any purchase must be in accordance with the approved BIL spend plan and directly supporting a BIL project. Regions must follow all current credit card processes; 192J is available in the credit card bot. 3. Reports The following is a list of Pegasys reports that have been created to include fund 192J financial activity. Business Intelligence (BI) databases will be updated to include transactions from 192J. These reports can be found directly in Pegasys or in BI. 8 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A   FR83AB   Allowance/Budget Plan Status Report   Trial Balance Report   Month-end Obligation Status Reports Income & Expense (I&E) Reports     Fixed Asset Trial Balance Report     ULO Database   Quarterly Commitments and Obligations Report for quarterly reporting to Inventory Status Report Congress (as requested in the act) Additionally, activity will be tracked on the below dashboard as updated by PBS and OCFO:   PMO Financial Tracking Report 4. General & Administration Allocation Fund 192J transactions that are coded without a building number, project number or RWA number will go into the various PBS G&A pools; the particular pool classification will depend on the distribution level of the organization code, just as with other Fund 192 indirect transactions. Likewise, fund 192J direct transactions against a particular building will factor into the distribution of the G&A pools just as with other Fund 192 direct transactions. All regions should evaluate the impact of 192J funding on their workloads when determining the new workload factors for FY23 and forward. As most 192J funding is anticipated to be related to capital projects, regions should pay special attention to the impact on the capitalization factors. The Pegasys cost allocation module and the I&E reports will include the 192J fund transactions in with the other Fund 192 transactions to produce one official set of regional and nationwide FBF I&E reports. For more information, please contact Stefanie Crane at 202-528-8178. 5. Cost Transfers Cost transfers occur after funds are expensed. Cost transfers often correct coding errors or reflect changes in coding decisions. They do not require approval by OMB or Congress, but may require explanation after the fact to OMB, Congress or auditors. Cost transfers can be between funds, budget activities, or projects. Because of the BIL's unique requirements for transparency and because of the multiple levels of review for BIL obligations and expenses, cost transfers initiated by regions are strongly discouraged. No cost transfers may be initiated without prior approval from the OCFO Zonal RWA/Capital Projects Director with the concurrence of BBP. Regions shall request cost transfers between the FBF (192X) and the BIL fund (192J) only when the original obligation is clearly in error, or when the identified scope is clearly miscoded. Likewise, regions will request cost transfers between Budget Activities within 192J only when the original obligation is in error. 9 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A All requests for cost transfers must be submitted by the zonal OCFO capital projects budget analyst and must be submitted to the OCFO Zonal RWA/Capital ProjectsDirector for concurrence, and finally to the BBP Capital Projects team for review and concurrence. This process is for approval only. Once the request is approved, the region must transfer the costs by following normal procedures. F. Property In addition to the PBS Property Accounting Handbook, the following guidance is provided to address the specific changes that must be accomplished due to the BIL. 1. Establishing 192J Funded Projects Projects exceeding $50,000 from 192J funds must be assigned a capitalized Accounting System Identification (ASID) in PBS s Inventory Reporting Information System (IRIS), while projects under $50,000 must be assigned an expensed ASID. Because it is PBS  s policy to capitalize at the ASID level, only one ASID should be used even if the project is funded through 192X and 192J. If the ASID is funded by 192X and 192J, IRIS users need to indicate in the appropriate field that the project is multiple funded and select the corresponding Budget Activity. If a project is funded solely from 192J, the ASID number will be assigned based on the type of work conducted, similar to PBS s process under 192X. Each ASID number should tie back to the original project line item number (or LIN) and, while each project can have multiple ASIDs, there must only be one project line item number for each 192J funded project. New construction projects must continue to be assigned N- type ASIDs. These ASIDs will be funded from Budget Activities PG11 (CBP LPOE Five Year Plan Projects), PG12 (AJP Priority LPOE Projects), PG13 (LPOE Paving, Acquisition of Leased LPOE, and FMCSA Projects) and PG14 (Project Contingency). Should a region have a blended new construction/R&A project, please consult with zonal budget and BBP. Repair and Alteration (R&A) projects exceeding the current prospectus limit will continue to be assigned V-type ASIDs for construction and non-advanced design. Currently, there are no advanced design projects that should be assigned S-type ASIDs under 192J. All R&A projects under prospectus will be assigned R-type ASIDs. The spending plan will list the appropriate budget activities and ASID types to be recorded into IRIS for these projects. Traditionally, LPOE project are funded through new construction using N-type ASIDs; however, depending on the scope of the project, the project may need to be coded as a R&A project and could be funded from PG11-PG14 (if deemed necessary and approved by BBP and the Capital Assessment and Allocation Division (PTB)). Should there be any operating costs funded by BIL, ASIDs will not be required for PG15 (Operating Costs). 10 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A PG14 funds will be used as a source for additional project contingency through a stringent governance process managed by the PMO. Regions should plan to stay within the standard construction contingency for their projects, which is already part of the PG11, 12 and 13 project budgets as included in the spend plan. Regions will need approval from the PMO to receive a budget increase from the PG14 program contingency. If approved, funds will be allowed in PG14 and the contingency accounting string will need to be used on the project. Therefore, PG14 costs related to a specific construction project must cite the N, S, V, or R-type ASID for that project and use the same LIN. Fund type 192J: Budget Activity Line item type PG11 PG12 PG13 PG14 PG15 N, L, R N, L, R N, L, R N, L, R n/a ASID type N, V, R N, V, R N, V, R N, V, R R An IRIS National Priority Code is not needed for Fund 192J. IRIS now has the capability to assign ASIDs to the 192J funded budget activities. As previously discussed, IRIS users need to check the multiple fund indicator for the ASID with the appropriate Budget Activity Code in IRIS. For any environmental-related cleanup costs, a separate ASID with expensed accounting treatment will need to be established for any environmental work items. See Chief Financial Officer Manual, Volume 3, OCFO 4260.3 (May 23, 2019), Chapter 5: Expenses, Part 4 for more details. 2. Monitoring Capitalized Projects As PBS receives additional funding under 192J for existing projects, the capitalization status of projects may change since the scope of work and/or dollar amount may change. For example, if a project originally was expensed since it was primarily for repairs, but additional funding allows PBS to improve the asset beyond its original condition, it must be capitalized if it exceeds PBS s capitalization threshold of $50,000. The capitalization threshold is based on the ASID s delivered orders under both funds and under all budget activities. If a project's capitalization status changes, the Regional IRIS Power User must first adjust the work category code and send an email to PBS.Property@gsa.gov informing BGP of the change and reason. The BGP Property Team will then request financial system adjustments as needed. 11 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A Estimated Substantial Completion Date (ESCD): The ESCD is the planned date for the asset to be ready for its intended purpose, regardless of funding code. The estimated SCD should be updated and maintained in IRIS throughout the life of the project. If the scope of work will change due to additional 192J funds, regional associates should adjust the date as soon as a date is established. Additionally, study, design, and construction award dates should also be entered as incurred to ensure IRIS reflects the proper project status. Actual Substantial Completion Date (ASCD): The ASCD is the actual date the asset can be operated or occupied, even though minor repairs or construction may be needed. It is the date when PBS inspects, approves and determines that work has been performed to bring the project to the degree of completion that is necessary for the asset to be used for its intended purpose. Associated construction or physical, or financial completion dates, that are associated with the project shall not delay reporting of the ASCD. Depreciation: Once the project reaches substantial completion and the ASCD is entered into IRIS, project costs will transfer from the construction-in-process to the completed buildings accounts and depreciation will be recorded. The useful lives of projects, which are based on project type, will remain unchanged, regardless if funded completely or partly under fund 192J. For additional information related to Property, please contact Claudine Schleicher at 202-821-8342 or Amber Cochran at 202-236-7258. G. RWA Tracking The following guidance applies to RWA acceptance and processing for RWAs that support GSAs BIL projects, specifically RWAs from U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) for Furniture, Fixtures, and Equipment. Intake Process: Regions will follow standard PBS RWA policy (Reimbursable Work Authorizations National Policy Manual, PBS 1000.2B (August 1, 2020), as revised). In addition, BIL LPOE RWAs must be approved by the LPOE PMO before accepted by PBS. The LPOE PMO will maintain a list of projected CBP RWAs funded with CBP BIL funding. Note: CBP RWAs funded with BIL funding will contain the following TAS, which indicates the RWA is funded from BIL: 070 2022 2026 0530000 *070 is connected to CBP agency bureau code, then the year of the appropriation and the year of expiration of obligational authority. 0530 is an identifier for O&S projects (CBP s BIL projects) 12 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A Reminder: Any B-type RWAs must be associated with a Project Control Number and ASID code connecting it to the GSA-funded portion of the work (usually V-type or N- type). In addition, the associated PCN must be entered in the PCN field in RETA (see screenshot below). For additional assistance please contact your RWA financial point of contact. H. PBS Systems The following PBS systems have been modified to include the new fund 192J financial activity: a. Kahua b. Capital Projects Application (CPA) c. Business Intelligence/Business Objects d. RETA e. Inventory Reporting Information System (IRIS) 13 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A f. REXUS g. ULO database Because these systems rely heavily on templates, not every system can accept every possible combination of fund code, budget activity code, organization code, and project code. If you have trouble entering obligations or other transactions, please first check to be sure that you have made no errors, then contact your local budget analyst for further assistance. I. FY 2022 and Beyond $3.418 billion in BIL funding is available for FY22 and beyond as no-year funding. Beginning with the FY2024 Budget Call, OCFO will start estimating impacts to budgets as a result of any completed BIL projects. For example, utilities, cleaning, and maintenance costs will need to be budgeted in the appropriate fiscal year for any new LPOEs or completed projects coming online. 14 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A
results.EO_Text: Federal Register Vol. 90, No. 71 Tuesday, April 15, 2025 Title 3  The President Presidential Documents 15615 Executive Order 14263 of April 9, 2025 Addressing Risks From Susman Godfrey By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, it is hereby ordered: Section 1. Background. Lawyers and law firms that engage in activities detrimental to critical American interests should not have access to our Nation s secrets, nor should their conduct be subsidized by Federal taxpayer funds or contracts. My Administration must also take appropriate and nec- essary measures to guard against the actual, potential, or perceived conflicts of interest that arise when the Government funds, engages with, or otherwise devotes resources to law firms and their clients that engage in conduct undermining critical American interests and priorities. I have determined that action is necessary to address the significant risks, egregious conduct, and conflicts of interest associated with Susman Godfrey LLP (Susman). Susman spearheads efforts to weaponize the American legal system and degrade the quality of American elections. Susman also funds groups that engage in dangerous efforts to undermine the effectiveness of the United States military through the injection of political and radical ideology, and it supports efforts to discriminate on the basis of race. Susman itself engages in unlawful discrimination, including discrimination on the basis of race. For example, Susman administers a program where it offers financial awards and employment opportunities only to  students of color.  My Administration is committed to ending such unlawful discrimi- nation perpetrated in the name of  diversity, equity, and inclusion  policies and ensuring that Federal benefits support the laws and policies of the United States, including those laws and policies promoting our national security and respecting the democratic process. Those who engage in blatant discrimination and other activities inconsistent with the interests of the United States should not have access to our Nation s secrets nor be deemed responsible stewards of any Federal funds. Sec. 2. Security Clearance Review. (a) The Attorney General, the Director of National Intelligence, and all other relevant heads of executive departments and agencies (agencies) shall immediately take steps consistent with applica- ble law to suspend any active security clearances held by individuals at Susman, pending a review of whether such clearances are consistent with the national interest. (b) The Office of Management and Budget shall identify all Government goods, property, material, and services, including Sensitive Compartmented Information Facilities, provided for the benefit of Susman. The heads of agencies providing such material or services shall, to the extent permitted by law, expeditiously cease such provision. Sec. 3. Contracting. (a) To prevent the transfer of taxpayer dollars to Federal contractors whose earnings subsidize, among other things, activities that are not aligned with American interests, including racial discrimination, Government contracting agencies shall, to the extent permissible by law, require Government contractors to disclose any business they do with Susman and whether that business is related to the subject of the Government contract. (b) The heads of agencies shall review all contracts with Susman or with entities that disclose doing business with Susman under subsection (a) of this section. To the extent permitted by law, the heads of agencies shall: VerDate Sep<11>2014 16:25 Apr 14, 2025 Jkt 265001 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 4705 Sfmt 4790 E:\FR\FM\15APE0.SGM 15APE0 0 C O D Z E R P _ R F h t i w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o r e t t o l 15616 Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 71 / Tuesday, April 15, 2025 / Presidential Documents (i) take appropriate steps to terminate any contract, to the maximum extent permitted by applicable law, including the Federal Acquisition Regulation, for which Susman has been hired to perform any service; and (ii) otherwise align their agency funding decisions with the interests of the citizens of the United States; with the goals and priorities of my Administration as expressed in executive actions, especially Executive Order 14147 of January 20, 2025 (Ending the Weaponization of the Federal Government); and as heads of agencies deem appropriate. Within 30 days of the date of this order, agencies shall submit to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget an assessment of contracts with Susman or with entities that do business with Susman effective as of the date of this order and any actions taken with respect to those contracts in accordance with this order. Sec. 4. Racial Discrimination. Nothing in this order shall be construed to limit the action authorized by section 4 of Executive Order 14230 of March 6, 2025 (Addressing Risks from Perkins Coie LLP). Sec. 5. Personnel. (a) The heads of agencies shall, to the extent permitted by law, provide guidance limiting official access from Federal Government buildings to employees of Susman when such access would threaten the national security of or otherwise be inconsistent with the interests of the United States. In addition, the heads of agencies shall provide guidance limiting Government employees acting in their official capacity from engaging with Susman employees to ensure consistency with the national security and other interests of the United States. (b) Agency officials shall, to the extent permitted by law, refrain from hiring employees of Susman, absent a waiver from the head of the agency, made in consultation with the Director of the Office of Personnel Manage- ment, that such hire will not threaten the national security of the United States. Sec. 6. General Provisions. (a) Nothing in this order shall be construed to impair or otherwise affect: (i) the authority granted by law to an executive department or agency, or the head thereof; or (ii) the functions of the Director of the Office of Management and Budget relating to budgetary, administrative, or legislative proposals. (b) This order shall be implemented consistent with applicable law and subject to the availability of appropriations. 0 C O D Z E R P _ R F h t i w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o r e t t o l VerDate Sep<11>2014 16:25 Apr 14, 2025 Jkt 265001 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 4705 Sfmt 4790 E:\FR\FM\15APE0.SGM 15APE0 Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 71 / Tuesday, April 15, 2025 / Presidential Documents 15617 (c) This order is not intended to, and does not, create any right or benefit, substantive or procedural, enforceable at law or in equity by any party against the United States, its departments, agencies, or entities, its officers, employees, or agents, or any other person. THE WHITE HOUSE, April 9, 2025. results.Summary:
Here's a comprehensive analysis of the policy document in light of the executive order:

1. Policy Summary:
The document is a GSA memorandum providing financial guidance for implementing the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA), specifically focused on:
- Establishing new accounting codes (Fund 192J)
- Creating budget activities for Land Ports of Entry (LPOE) projects
- Tracking PBS operating expenses related to the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law (BIL)
- Providing detailed instructions for fund management, project tracking, and financial reporting

2. Executive Order Summary:
The executive order targets Susman Godfrey LLP, alleging:
- Engaging in activities detrimental to American interests
- Discriminatory practices
- Potential national security risks

The order instructs federal agencies to:
- Review and suspend security clearances
- Terminate or review contracts
- Limit official interactions with the firm
- Restrict hiring from the firm

3. Applicability Analysis:
After careful review, this executive order DOES NOT directly impact the GSA infrastructure funding policy document. Reasons:
- The policy is a technical financial guidance document for IIJA implementation
- The executive order targets a specific law firm (Susman Godfrey)
- The policy document does not mention any contracts with or interactions with Susman Godfrey
- The funding and project guidelines remain unchanged by this order

4. Recommended Next Steps:
Although the executive order does not directly affect this policy, recommended actions include:
- Maintain current policy implementation
- Ensure continued transparency in contract and project reporting
- Review any existing contracts for potential conflicts
- Continue standard compliance and financial tracking procedures

Conclusion: No immediate policy modifications are required based on this executive order.

The policy's accounting, budgeting, and project tracking procedures remain unchanged by this order.
results.phase1_response:
TO: Distribution
FROM: GSA Policy Analyst
SUBJECT: Analysis of Executive Order 14263 on GSA Memo Dated September 28, 2022

This memorandum provides an analysis of Executive Order 14263 ("Addressing Risks From Susman Godfrey") and its impact on the GSA memorandum "Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act Financial Guidance" dated September 28, 2022.

### 1. Summary of Policy Text

The GSA memorandum provides detailed financial and accounting guidance for the $3.4 billion appropriated to the Federal Buildings Fund (FBF) by the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law (BIL). The policy establishes new accounting codes (Fund 192J), budget activities, and tracking procedures to manage and report on BIL funds separately from regular FBF funds (192X). It outlines processes for Public Buildings Service (PBS) personnel to request funds, manage projects in GSA's financial systems (Pegasys), and handle contracts, labor coding, and property capitalization for BIL-funded projects, which are primarily focused on Land Ports of Entry (LPOE). The document is fundamentally a "how-to" guide for the financial execution of the BIL program within GSA.

### 2. Summary of Executive Order Text

Executive Order 14263 directs all executive departments and agencies to take specific actions to address perceived risks associated with the law firm Susman Godfrey LLP ("Susman"). Citing allegations of activities detrimental to U.S. interests, including unlawful discrimination and undermining democratic processes, the EO mandates several actions. Key directives include:
*   Suspending security clearances held by individuals at Susman.
*   Requiring government contractors to disclose any business they conduct with Susman.
*   Reviewing and taking steps to terminate existing government contracts where Susman is performing a service or that are held by entities doing business with Susman.
*   Limiting Susman employees' access to federal facilities and interaction with federal employees.
*   Restricting the hiring of Susman employees into federal service.

### 3. Detailed Explanation of Applicability

The Executive Order applies to and directly affects the execution of the policy outlined in the GSA memorandum. While the memorandum does not name Susman Godfrey or any other specific law firm, its entire purpose is to govern the financial mechanisms through which GSA will obligate and expend $3.4 billion. A significant portion of these funds will be executed via contracts with external vendors for construction, design, management support, and other professional services. The Executive Order imposes new, government-wide requirements on this contracting process.

The specific points of impact are as follows:

*   **Contracting and Procurement (EO Sec. 3):** This is the most significant area of impact. The GSA memorandum's procedures for requesting allowances (Section D) are directly tied to pending contract awards. The Executive Order now mandates that GSA's procurement process for any BIL-funded project must include a new due diligence step.
    *   **Disclosure Requirement:** GSA contracting officers must now require all potential contractors for BIL projects to disclose any business they do with Susman Godfrey. This is a new material requirement for all solicitations.
    *   **Contract Review and Termination:** If an existing or potential contractor discloses a relationship with Susman, GSA is required to review that contract. If Susman is hired to perform any service under that contract, GSA is directed to take steps to terminate it. This adds a critical layer of compliance and risk assessment to the procurement and project management activities governed by the memorandum. For example, a prime construction contractor for an LPOE project that subcontracts legal services to Susman would be in violation of the EO's directive.
*   **Personnel (EO Sec. 5):** The GSA memorandum applies to a wide range of PBS and OCFO employees, including the LPOE Program Management Office (PMO). These employees are now subject to the EO's prohibitions on engaging with Susman employees in their official capacity and are restricted from hiring Susman employees, affecting GSA's own staffing decisions for program execution.
*   **Use of Funds:** The memorandum establishes budget activities (e.g., PG11-PG15) and accounting strings for BIL-related expenses. The Executive Order effectively places a new restriction on the use of these funds by prohibiting their flow to Susman, either directly through a GSA contract or indirectly through a prime contractor. This impacts how budget and project managers can execute their approved spending plans.

In essence, the GSA memorandum provides the financial framework for the BIL program, and the Executive Order adds a critical compliance overlay that dictates with whom GSA and its contractors can and cannot do business.

### 4. Next Steps to Achieve Compliance

To ensure compliance with Executive Order 14263, the following actions must be taken immediately regarding the execution of BIL funds:

1.  **Issue Supplemental Guidance:** A follow-on memorandum must be issued to the same distribution list as the original policy, notifying all relevant personnel of the new requirements mandated by the Executive Order.
2.  **Update Procurement and Contracting Procedures:**
    *   The Office of Acquisition Policy and the Public Buildings Service must immediately develop and incorporate standard language into all new BIL-related solicitations (RFPs, RFQs, etc.) requiring contractors to disclose any business relationship with Susman Godfrey LLP, per Section 3(a) of the EO.
    *   Guidance must be provided to all Contracting Officers (COs) and Contracting Officer's Representatives (CORs) working on BIL projects on how to evaluate these disclosures and the steps to take if a prohibited relationship is identified.
3.  **Review Existing Contracts and Vendor Files:** The LPOE PMO, in coordination with regional contracting officers, must conduct a review of all existing BIL-related contracts and task orders to identify any potential engagement with Susman Godfrey.
4.  **Brief Affected Personnel:** All personnel identified in the "MEMORANDUM FOR" line of the original policy, particularly those in the LPOE PMO and regional design, construction, and financial offices, must be briefed on the restrictions regarding official interactions with and the hiring of Susman employees.
5.  **Coordinate with the Office of General Counsel (OGC):** OGC should review the required procurement language and provide legal guidance on the process for contract review and potential termination as stipulated in the EO.

---
**Final Determination: Affected**
results.phase2_justification:
1.  **The specific domain/subject area of the policy:** The policy, "Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act Financial Guidance," is a GSA internal memorandum that establishes the specific financial, accounting, and administrative procedures for managing and tracking the $3.4 billion appropriated by the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law (BIL) for Land Ports of Entry projects. Its domain is purely internal financial administration, covering topics like new accounting codes (Fund 192J), budget activities, allowance request processes, and the use of GSA's financial systems (Pegasys).

2.  **The specific domain/subject area of the executive order:** Executive Order 14263, "Addressing Risks from Susman Godfrey," is a government-wide directive targeting a specific private law firm. Its domain is federal contracting, security clearance, and personnel policy. It directs federal agencies to suspend security clearances, require contractors to disclose business with the named firm, review and potentially terminate associated contracts, and limit the hiring of the firm's employees.

3.  **Detailed analysis of whether there is direct or indirect impact:** The Executive Order has a clear, albeit indirect, impact on the activities governed by the GSA policy. The policy provides the financial mechanism and procedures to fund infrastructure projects. These projects are executed through contracts with private sector companies. The Executive Order imposes new, substantive requirements on all federal contracting activities. Therefore, while the EO does not alter the GSA's accounting codes or financial processes themselves, it directly impacts the procurement activities that these financial processes are designed to support. GSA, in executing the BIL projects described in its policy, must now adhere to the EO's requirements for any contract it funds.

4.  **Key language or provisions that support your determination:**
    *   **Policy Text:** The GSA memorandum repeatedly refers to activities that fall under federal procurement rules. For instance, it details the allowance process "as regions prepare to make awards" and requires supporting documents like "the contractor's proposal (i.e., Standard Form 1442)." It also mentions "Management Support contract employees." These are the precise activities the EO targets.
    *   **EO Text:** Section 3, "Contracting," is the central provision. It requires that "Government contracting agencies shall... require Government contractors to disclose any business they do with Susman" and directs agency heads to "review all contracts with... entities that disclose doing business with Susman." GSA is a government contracting agency, and the funds administered under its BIL policy will be used to award such contracts.

5.  **Any nuances or edge cases considered in your assessment:** The impact is categorized as indirect because the EO does not amend the text or procedures within the GSA memorandum. GSA can still use Fund 192J and follow its allowance request process. However, the impact is significant and unavoidable. Before an award can be made using the funds managed by this policy, GSA must incorporate the EO's new vetting, disclosure, and review requirements into its procurement process for these projects. The policy governs the 'how to pay,' while the EO governs the 'who can be paid,' creating a direct operational linkage.

Purpose This directive defines and prescribes the GSA policy on harassment (sexual harassment, non- sexual harassment, and sexual misconduct). This policy supports GSA s well-established commitment to providing a workplace free from harassment. This policy ensures that GSA is taking all reasonable steps to prevent harassment from occurring and to address such conduct before it becomes unlawful. 2. Background Harassment in the Federal workplace is defined as any unwelcome conduct, including oral, written, physical or on-line conduct, based on an individual s membership in a group as described in Section 7(b) below. Harassment also includes retaliation, which is adverse action taken against an individual because the individual reported harassment, supported https://insite.gsa.gov/directives-library/general-services-administration-gsa-policy-statement-on-harassment-including-sexual-and-nonsexual 1/4 2/6/25, 2:16 PM General Services Administration (GSA) Policy Statement on Harassment, Including Sexual and Non-sexual another individual s harassment claim, or opposed harassing conduct. 3. Responsibilities a. The Associate Administrator for GSA s Office of Civil Rights (OCR) is responsible for developing and disseminating this policy. b. The Chief Human Capital Officer for GSA s Office of Human Resources Management (OHRM) is responsible for administering GSA s Anti-Harassment Procedures in the Workplace (Anti-Harassment Procedures). c. Managers and supervisors are responsible for carrying out the provisions of this policy by: (i.) maintaining an environment free from harassment; (ii.) ensuring that individuals who engage in protected EEO activity are not subject to retaliation; (iii.) cooperating with investigations of harassment complaints; and (iv.) reporting to OHRM any harassing conduct witnessed, or reports or complaints of harassing conduct received. d. Employees are responsible for abiding by this policy by promptly reporting any conduct that violates this policy, and fully cooperating in any investigation of harassment. 4. results.EO_Text: Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 71 / Tuesday, April 15, 2025 / Presidential Documents 15629 Presidential Documents Executive Order 14267 of April 9, 2025 Reducing Anti-Competitive Regulatory Barriers By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, it is hereby ordered: Section 1. Purpose. Federal regulations should not predetermine economic winners and losers. Yet some regulations operate to exclude new market entrants. Regulations that reduce competition, entrepreneurship, and innova- tion as well as the benefits they create for American consumers should be eliminated. This order commences the process for eliminating anti-com- petitive regulations to revitalize the American economy. Sec. 2. Definitions. (a)  Agency  has the meaning given to it in section 3502 of title 44, United States Code, except that it does not include the Executive Office of the President or any components thereof. (b)  Agency head  means the highest-ranking official of an agency, such as the Secretary, Administrator, Chairman, or Director, unless otherwise specified in this order. Sec. 3. Rescinding Anti-Competitive Regulations. (a) Agency heads shall, in consultation with the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission (Chair- man) and the Attorney General, complete a review of all regulations subject to their rulemaking authority and identify those that: (i) create, or facilitate the creation of, de facto or de jure monopolies; (ii) create unnecessary barriers to entry for new market participants; (iii) limit competition between competing entities or have the effect of limiting competition between competing entities; (iv) create or facilitate licensure or accreditation requirements that unduly limit competition; (v) unnecessarily burden the agency s procurement processes, thereby lim- iting companies  ability to compete for procurements; or (vi) otherwise impose anti-competitive restraints or distortions on the oper- ation of the free market. (b) Within 70 days of the date of this order, agency heads shall each provide to the Chairman and the Attorney General a list of regulations identified by the categories specified in subsection (a) of this section. Agency heads shall also include a recommendation as to whether each of the listed regulations warrants rescission or modification in light of its anti-competitive effects. For recommended modifications, agency heads shall briefly specify what modification is appropriate. For regulations that are anti-competitive by design, agency heads shall provide a justification for their anti-competitive effects if the agency head is not proposing rescission or modification. (c) In conducting the review required by subsection (a) of this section, agency heads shall prioritize review of those rules that satisfy the definition of  significant regulatory action  in Executive Order 12866 of September 30, 1993 (Regulatory Planning and Review), as amended. (d) Within 10 days of the date of this order, the Chairman shall issue a request for information (RFI) that seeks public input on the identification of regulations that fall within the categories specified in subsection (a) of this section, as well as comments explaining the proposed classifications. The request shall remain open for 40 days. The Chairman may include on the consolidated list regulations not originally included on an agency list if such regulations fall within at least one of the categories outlined in subsections (a)(i)  (vi) of this section. (f) Upon receipt of the consolidated list described in subsection (e) of this section, the OMB Director, through the Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, shall consult with the Chairman, the Attorney General, the Assistant to the President for Economic Policy, and the relevant agency heads to decide whether to incorporate the proposed rescissions or modifications into the Unified Regulatory Agenda developed pursuant to Executive Order 14219 of February 19, 2025 (Ensuring Lawful Governance and Implementing the President s  Department of Government Efficiency  Deregulatory Initiative). Sec. 4. General Provisions. (a) Nothing in this order shall be construed to impair or otherwise affect: (i) the authority granted by law to an executive department or agency, or the head thereof; or (ii) the functions of the Director of the Office of Management and Budget relating to budgetary, administrative, or legislative proposals. (b) This order shall be implemented consistent with applicable law and subject to the availability of appropriations. (c) This order is not intended to, and does not, create any right or benefit, substantive or procedural, enforceable at law or in equity by any party against the United States, its departments, agencies, or entities, its officers, employees, or agents, or any other person. 4 C O D Z E R P _ R F h t i w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o r e t t o l THE WHITE HOUSE, April 9, 2025. results.Summary:
Here's my analysis of the policy and executive order:

1. Policy Summary:
The GSA Policy Statement on Harassment (2325.8A) defines and prescribes guidelines for preventing harassment in the workplace. Key points include:
- Defines harassment as unwelcome conduct based on group membership
- Applies to GSA employees, former employees, and job applicants
- Outlines responsibilities for the Office of Civil Rights, Human Resources, managers, and employees
- Focuses on maintaining a workplace free from harassment
- Excludes the Office of Inspector General and Civilian Board of Contract Appeals from full applicability

2. Executive Order Summary:
Executive Order 14267 aims to reduce anti-competitive regulatory barriers by:
- Requiring agency heads to review regulations that:
  - Create monopolies
  - Create barriers to market entry
  - Limit competition
  - Impose unnecessary licensure requirements
  - Burden procurement processes
- Mandates agencies identify and potentially rescind anti-competitive regulations
- Involves consultation with the Federal Trade Commission and Attorney General
- Seeks to revitalize the American economy by eliminating restrictive regulations

3. Applicability Analysis:
The executive order does NOT directly impact the GSA Harassment Policy because:
- The policy is an internal workplace conduct guideline
- It does not create economic barriers or limit market competition
- The order focuses on economic and regulatory constraints, not workplace conduct policies
- The harassment policy falls under civil rights and workplace safety, not economic regulation

4. Compliance Recommendation:
No specific actions are required for this policy under the executive order. The GSA should:
- Maintain the current harassment policy
- Continue to follow existing workplace conduct guidelines
- Monitor future executive orders that might affect workplace policies

Recommendation Confidence: High

Note: This analysis is based on the documents provided and represents a professional interpretation of their interaction.
results.updated_summary: The Executive Order 14267 focuses exclusively on economic regulatory barriers and does not have any mechanisms that would directly or indirectly modify internal workplace conduct policies like the GSA's harassment prevention guidelines. The policy's purpose of maintaining a safe workplace remains unchanged by this economic deregulation order.
results.phase1_response:
**MEMORANDUM**

**To:** GSA Leadership
**From:** Policy Analyst
**Date:** October 26, 2023
**Subject:** Analysis of Executive Order 14267 Impact on GSA Policy 2325.8A (Harassment Policy)

This memorandum provides an analysis of Executive Order (EO) 14267, "Reducing Anti-Competitive Regulatory Barriers," and its potential impact on GSA Policy Statement 2325.8A, "GSA Policy Statement on Harassment, Including Sexual and Non-sexual."

### 1. Summary of GSA Policy 2325.8A

GSA Policy 2325.8A is an internal administrative directive that defines and prescribes the agency's policy on harassment. Its purpose is to ensure a workplace free from sexual and non-sexual harassment, including retaliation. The policy outlines the responsibilities of the Office of Civil Rights, the Office of Human Resources Management, managers, and employees in preventing, reporting, and addressing harassing conduct. It applies to GSA employees, former employees, and applicants, with specific exceptions for the Office of Inspector General and the Civilian Board of Contract Appeals due to their independent personnel authorities. In essence, it is an internal personnel and civil rights policy focused on workplace conduct.

### 2. Summary of Executive Order 14267

Executive Order 14267 directs federal agencies to review and identify regulations that create unnecessary barriers to economic competition. The stated purpose is to eliminate rules that reduce entrepreneurship, innovation, and the benefits they create for consumers. Agency heads are required to identify regulations that create monopolies, limit market entry, stifle competition between entities, impose undue licensure requirements, burden procurement processes, or otherwise distort the free market. The EO establishes a process for agencies to report these regulations for potential modification or rescission.

### 3. Detailed Explanation of Applicability

Executive Order 14267 **does not apply** to GSA Policy 2325.8A. The determination is based on the fundamental difference in the subject matter, scope, and purpose of the two documents.

*   **Subject Matter Mismatch:** The EO is exclusively focused on **economic regulations** that affect the external free market. Its criteria, listed in Section 3(a), are all related to market competition, such as creating monopolies, barriers to entry for new businesses, and limiting competition in procurement. GSA's harassment policy, in contrast, is an **internal personnel policy** concerned with workplace conduct, employee rights, and ensuring a safe and respectful professional environment.
*   **Scope and Target:** The EO targets "regulations subject to [agency] rulemaking authority" that impact external market participants, consumers, and competing businesses. GSA Policy 2325.8A is an internal directive that governs the conduct of GSA's own employees and applicants. It does not regulate any external market, industry, or private-sector activity.
*   **Failure to Meet Criteria:** The harassment policy does not meet any of the specific criteria for review outlined in Section 3(a) of the EO:
    *   It does not create or facilitate monopolies.
    *   It does not create barriers to entry for new market participants.
    *   It does not limit competition between entities.
    *   It does not create licensure or accreditation requirements.
    *   It does not burden the agency's procurement processes to limit competition.
    *   It does not impose any anti-competitive restraints or distortions on the operation of the free market.

In summary, the harassment policy is a matter of internal agency administration and management, falling outside the economic and market-based scope of Executive Order 14267.

### 4. Next Steps for Compliance

Because GSA Policy 2325.8A is not affected by this Executive Order, no specific compliance actions are required for this policy. It does not need to be included in the list of regulations submitted to the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission and the Attorney General as mandated by Section 3(b) of the EO.

GSA's review in response to EO 14267 should proceed by focusing on external-facing regulations, particularly those related to federal procurement, real property, and acquisition services that could potentially impact market competition.

---

**Final Determination: Not Affected**
results.phase2_justification:
1.  **The specific domain/subject area of the policy**: The policy, 2325.8A ADM, is an internal General Services Administration (GSA) directive focused on personnel management, civil rights, and workplace conduct. Its stated purpose is to define and prescribe the GSA's policy on harassment to ensure a workplace free from such behavior. It governs the conduct of GSA employees, former employees, and applicants, and outlines internal procedures for reporting and investigation.

2.  **The specific domain/subject area of the executive order**: Executive Order (EO) 14267, "Reducing Anti-Competitive Regulatory Barriers," operates in the domain of economic and regulatory policy. Its purpose is to identify and eliminate federal regulations that hinder free-market competition, create barriers to entry for new businesses, or otherwise distort the economy.

3.  **Detailed analysis of whether there is direct or indirect impact**: There is no direct or indirect impact of EO 14267 on GSA Policy 2325.8A. The two documents address fundamentally different and unrelated subject areas. The policy is concerned with internal agency culture and employee conduct, while the EO is concerned with the external economic effects of federal regulations on the public marketplace. The GSA's internal anti-harassment policy does not regulate commerce, influence market dynamics, or create barriers for businesses seeking to compete in the market.

4.  **Key language or provisions that support your determination**:
    *   **EO 14267 Section 3(a)** directs agencies to identify regulations that "create unnecessary barriers to entry for new market participants," "limit competition between competing entities," or "impose anti-competitive restraints or distortions on the operation of the free market."
    *   **GSA Policy 2325.8A Section 1** states its purpose is to "define and prescribe the GSA policy on harassment...to [provide] a workplace free from harassment."
    *   A comparison of these core provisions shows a clear divergence in intent and scope. The GSA's internal harassment policy does not meet any of the criteria outlined in the Executive Order for review, as it is not an economic regulation.

5.  **Any nuances or edge cases considered in your assessment**: While EO 14267 Section 3(a)(v) mentions reviewing regulations that "unnecessarily burden the agency’s procurement processes," the GSA's harassment policy does not govern procurement. Its scope, as defined in Section 4, is limited to GSA employees, former employees, and applicants for employment. It is an internal personnel directive, not a procurement regulation, and therefore has no bearing on the ability of external companies to compete for government contracts. The initial "Not Affected" flag is correct.

results.EO_Name: Establishment of the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and United States Digital Asset Stockpile
results.EO_Filename_Text: Establishment of the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and United States Digital Asset Stockpile.pdf
results.EO_Text: Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 46 / Tuesday, March 11, 2025 / Presidential Documents 11789 Presidential Documents Executive Order 14233 of March 6, 2025 Establishment of the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and United States Digital Asset Stockpile By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, it is hereby ordered: Section 1. Background. Bitcoin is the original cryptocurrency. The Bitcoin protocol permanently caps the total supply of bitcoin (BTC) at 21 million coins, and has never been hacked. As a result of its scarcity and security, Bitcoin is often referred to as  digital gold . Because there is a fixed supply of BTC, there is a strategic advantage to being among the first nations to create a strategic bitcoin reserve. The United States Government currently holds a significant amount of BTC, but has not implemented a policy to maximize BTC s strategic position as a unique store of value in the global financial system. Just as it is in our country s interest to thoughtfully manage national ownership and control of any other resource, our Nation must harness, not limit, the power of digital assets for our prosperity. Sec. 2. Policy. It is the policy of the United States to establish a Strategic Bitcoin Reserve. It is further the policy of the United States to establish a United States Digital Asset Stockpile that can serve as a secure account for orderly and strategic management of the United States  other digital asset holdings. Sec. 3. Creation and Administration of the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and United States Digital Asset Stockpile. (a) The Secretary of the Treasury shall establish an office to administer and maintain control of custodial accounts collectively known as the  Stra- tegic Bitcoin Reserve,  capitalized with all BTC held by the Department of the Treasury that was finally forfeited as part of criminal or civil asset forfeiture proceedings or in satisfaction of any civil money penalty imposed by any executive department or agency (agency) and that is not needed to satisfy requirements under 31 U.S.C. 9705 or released pursuant to sub- section (d) of this section (Government BTC). Within 30 days of the date of this order, each agency shall review its authorities to transfer any Govern- ment BTC held by it to the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and shall submit a report reflecting the result of that review to the Secretary of the Treasury. Government BTC deposited into the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve shall not be sold and shall be maintained as reserve assets of the United States utilized to meet governmental objectives in accordance with applicable law. Within 30 days of the date of this order, each agency shall review its authorities to transfer any Stockpile Assets held by it to the United States Digital Asset Stockpile and shall submit a report reflecting the result of that review to the Secretary of the Treasury. The Secretary of the Treasury shall determine strategies for responsible stewardship of the United States Digital Asset Stockpile in accordance with applicable law. results.Summary:
Analysis of GSA Policy Statement on Harassment and Executive Order 14233

1. Policy Summary:
The GSA Policy Statement on Harassment (Number 2325.8A) is a comprehensive directive that:
- Defines harassment in the federal workplace
- Establishes responsibilities for preventing and addressing harassment
- Applies to GSA employees, former employees, and job applicants
- Covers sexual harassment, non-sexual harassment, and sexual misconduct
- Outlines reporting and investigation procedures
- Includes specific exceptions for the Office of Inspector General (OIG) and Civilian Board of Contract Appeals (CBCA)

2. Executive Order Summary:
Executive Order 14233 establishes:
- A Strategic Bitcoin Reserve
- A United States Digital Asset Stockpile
- Procedures for managing government-owned digital assets
- Reporting requirements for federal agencies regarding digital asset holdings

3. Applicability Analysis:
The executive order does NOT directly impact the GSA Harassment Policy for the following reasons:
- The executive order focuses exclusively on digital asset management
- The harassment policy deals with workplace conduct and employee protections
- There are no provisions in the executive order that modify workplace harassment policies
- The policy's scope and objectives remain unchanged

4. Compliance Next Steps:
No immediate action is required to align the harassment policy with this executive order. However, standard organizational best practices suggest:
- Maintaining current harassment prevention protocols
- Continuing to enforce existing anti-harassment guidelines
- Keeping the policy document updated through regular reviews
- Monitoring any future executive orders that might impact workplace policies

Recommendation: No policy modification is necessary based on Executive Order 14233.

results.phase1_response:
**MEMORANDUM FOR THE RECORD**

**TO:** File
**FROM:** GSA Policy Analyst
**DATE:** March 11, 2025
**SUBJECT:** Analysis of Executive Order 14233 on GSA Policy Statement 2325.8A ADM (Harassment)

This memorandum provides an analysis of Executive Order (EO) 14233, "Establishment of the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and United States Digital Asset Stockpile," and its potential impact on the General Services Administration (GSA) Policy Statement 2325.8A ADM, "GSA Policy Statement on Harassment, Including Sexual and Non-sexual."

### 1. Summary of GSA Policy 2325.8A ADM

GSA Policy Statement 2325.8A ADM defines and prescribes the agency's policy on all forms of harassment, including sexual and non-sexual harassment, sexual misconduct, and retaliation. The policy's stated purpose is to support GSA’s commitment to a workplace free from harassment and to ensure that the agency takes all reasonable steps to prevent and address such conduct. It outlines the responsibilities of the Office of Civil Rights (OCR), the Office of Human Resources Management (OHRM), managers, supervisors, and employees in maintaining a harassment-free environment. The policy applies to all GSA employees, former employees, and applicants, with specific exceptions for the Office of Inspector General (OIG) and the Civilian Board of Contract Appeals (CBCA). This specific version of the policy was signed on August 21, 2023, and is noted as being canceled on February 6, 2025.

### 2. Summary of Executive Order 14233

Executive Order 14233, issued on March 6, 2025, establishes a national policy to create a "Strategic Bitcoin Reserve" and a "United States Digital Asset Stockpile." The order directs the Secretary of the Treasury to establish offices to administer these accounts. The assets funding these reserves are primarily Bitcoin (BTC) and other digital assets that the U.S. Government holds as a result of criminal or civil asset forfeiture proceedings. The EO requires all federal agencies to conduct an accounting of any such "Government Digital Assets" in their possession within 30 days and report their findings to the Secretary of the Treasury. It also sets guidelines for the transfer, management, and potential disposition of these assets.

### 3. Analysis of Applicability

Executive Order 14233 **does not apply to or affect** GSA Policy 2325.8A ADM. The two documents operate in entirely separate and unrelated domains of federal policy and administration.

*   **Subject Matter:** The GSA policy is a personnel and civil rights directive focused on workplace conduct, human behavior, and the prevention of harassment. Its entire scope is limited to the interactions between and responsibilities of GSA employees. In contrast, the Executive Order is a fiscal and asset management directive focused on the accounting, custody, and strategic management of a specific class of government property: cryptocurrency and other digital assets.
*   **Jurisdiction and Scope:** The GSA policy governs the conduct of people within the agency. The Executive Order governs the management of non-human assets held by federal agencies. There is no topical overlap between preventing workplace harassment and managing a national stockpile of forfeited digital assets.
*   **Agency Obligations:** While the Executive Order imposes obligations on GSA as a federal agency (specifically, the requirement to inventory and report any holdings of forfeited digital assets), these obligations fall within the purview of GSA's financial or asset management offices, such as the Office of the Chief Financial Officer (OCFO), not the Office of Civil Rights or the Office of Human Resources Management, which are responsible for the harassment policy. The actions required by the EO have no bearing on the content, purpose, or implementation of the anti-harassment policy.

### 4. Next Steps for Compliance

As the executive order does not affect the policy, **no steps are required to bring Policy 2325.8A ADM into compliance with EO 14233.**

The obligations created by EO 14233 for the GSA as a whole would need to be addressed by the appropriate GSA offices responsible for asset management. This would involve conducting the required 30-day accounting of any "Government Digital Assets" held by GSA and reporting the findings to the Secretary of the Treasury. This process is entirely independent of the agency's harassment policy.

***

**Final Determination: Not Affected**
results.phase2_justification:
1.  **The specific domain/subject area of the policy:** The policy, GSA 2325.8A ADM, is exclusively focused on personnel management and workplace conduct within the General Services Administration (GSA). Its purpose is to define and prohibit harassment (both sexual and non-sexual), establish a process for reporting and investigating such conduct, and assign responsibilities to GSA employees and leadership to maintain a harassment-free workplace. This is an internal agency policy concerning civil rights and employee behavior.

2.  **The specific domain/subject area of the executive order:** The executive order, EO 14233, operates in the domain of national financial policy and asset management. Its purpose is to establish a "Strategic Bitcoin Reserve" and a "United States Digital Asset Stockpile" under the administration of the Secretary of the Treasury. The order mandates that federal agencies account for and transfer their holdings of forfeited digital currencies to these new reserves.

3.  **Detailed analysis of whether there is direct or indirect impact:** There is no direct or indirect impact of EO 14233 on GSA Policy 2325.8A ADM. The two documents are thematically and operationally unrelated. The executive order concerns the management of a specific class of government assets (cryptocurrency), while the policy concerns the rules of conduct for government employees. The EO's requirement for GSA to potentially account for and transfer digital assets is a financial/administrative task; it does not alter the definitions, responsibilities, or procedures outlined in GSA's anti-harassment policy. The standards of behavior for GSA employees performing their duties, including any duties arising from this EO, would still be governed by the existing, unaffected harassment policy.

4.  **Key language or provisions that support your determination:**
    *   **Policy Purpose:** "This directive defines and prescribes the GSA policy on harassment (sexual harassment, non-sexual harassment, and sexual misconduct). This policy supports GSA’s well-established commitment to providing a workplace free from harassment." This clearly limits its scope to workplace conduct.
    *   **EO Policy Section:** "It is the policy of the United States to establish a Strategic Bitcoin Reserve. It is further the policy of the United States to establish a United States Digital Asset Stockpile..." This language establishes a financial and strategic objective, with no mention of personnel matters, workplace culture, or civil rights.

5.  **Any nuances or edge cases considered in your assessment:** One might consider whether GSA holds any forfeited digital assets that would subject it to the EO's directives. Even if GSA does, its obligation is limited to accounting for and transferring these assets. This administrative function does not create a new context for harassment or modify the existing policy. The policy on harassment is a foundational rule of workplace conduct that applies to all work performed by GSA employees, regardless of the specific task. The EO does not intersect with the substance of this rule in any way. Therefore, the policy is not affected.

results.Policy Text: 2/6/25, 2:21 PM Prioritizing GSA Response to the Climate Crisis An official website of the United States government InSite < Back to List Prioritizing GSA Response to the Climate Crisis Number: 1100.1 ADM Status: Active Signature Date: 01/25/2023 Expiration Date: 01/25/2030 Service/Staff Office: Office of the Administrator GENERAL SERVICES ADMINISTRATION Washington, DC 20405 ADM 1100.1 January 25, 2023 GSA ORDER SUBJECT: Prioritizing GSA Response to the Climate Crisis [PDF - 29 KB] 1. Purpose. This Order provides an implementation framework for GSA s response to the ongoing climate crisis, through activities intended to (a) achieve  net zero  operational and procurement-related carbon emissions and (b) adapt GSA facilities, operations, and supply chains to withstand observed and expected climate conditions. 2. Background. a. Executive Order 14057,  Catalyzing Clean Energy Industries and Jobs Through Federal Sustainability,  ( E.O. 14057 ) signed on December 8, 2021, along with its accompanying OMB Order M-22-06 and White House Council https://insite.gsa.gov/directives-library/prioritizing-gsa-response-to-the-climate-crisis 1/2 2/6/25, 2:21 PM Prioritizing GSA Response to the Climate Crisis on Environmental Quality (CEQ) Implementing Instructions, notes that  the Federal Government faces broad exposure to the mounting risks and costs already posed by the climate crisis.  In response, E.O. 14057 directs numerous specific agency actions in furtherance of seven government-wide goals including: (i) 100 percent carbon pollution-free electricity by 2030, including 50 percent 24/7 carbon pollution-free electricity; (ii) 100 percent zero-emission vehicle acquisitions by 2035, including 100 percent zero-emission light-duty vehicle acquisitions by 2027; (iii) a net-zero emissions building portfolio by 2045, including a 50 percent emissions reduction by 2032; (iv) a 65 percent reduction in scope 1 and 2 greenhouse gas emissions from Federal operations by 2030 from 2008 levels; (v) net- zero emissions from Federal procurement; (vi) climate resilient infrastructure and operations; and (vii) a climate- and sustainability-focused Federal workforce.
